The silence stretched, filled only by the drumming of rain on the glass and the occasional, distant rumble of thunder. For Max, the quiet was no longer comfortable. It was electric, a high-tension wire humming between them. Every tiny movement Leo made—the shift of his weight on the minimalist sofa that probably cost more than his van, the way his thumb absently traced the rim of the mug—was magnified, imbued with a significance that made Max’s heart ache. He felt like he was seeing in colour for the first time, and the intensity of it was overwhelming. He had spent his life honing his body into a perfect instrument of force and precision, yet here he was, undone by the sight of a man’s earth-stained hands.

"The silver birch should be okay," Leo said, his voice pulling Max from his daze. He was looking out at the maelstrom, his expression thoughtful. "Her roots are deep enough now. But I worry about the delphiniums. They're all height and no sense, that lot." He offered a small, self-deprecating smile, as if embarrassed by his open affection for the plants. "They'll be flattened if this keeps up."

"Right," Max said, the word sounding hollow and strange in his own mouth. He cleared his throat. "The delphiniums." He tried to picture them, to care about them, but all he could think about was the proximity of Leo’s shoulder to his own, the clean, damp scent of him that had displaced the sterile nothingness of the house. He wanted to say something real, something that wasn't about the weather or the garden, but the vocabulary for such a thing had been stripped from him long ago, replaced by media-trained soundbites.

The worst of the storm passed as quickly as it had arrived. The violent drumming on the windows softened to a steady, rhythmic patter, and a watery, grey light began to seep back into the sky. Leo drained his mug and placed it carefully on the low-slung marble table between them, using the coaster Max had forgotten was even there. He seemed to sense the moment was over, that his presence in this alien environment was temporary, like the storm itself.

"I should go," Leo said, rising to his feet. "The light's fading. Thank you for the tea, Max. And for the… rescue." He gestured vaguely towards the window, a flicker of that genuine smile returning. He stood on the edge of the expensive rug, once again conscious of his damp, work-worn state. "I'll try not to drip on my way out."

"Don't worry about it," Max said, getting up too quickly. The silence that would follow Leo's departure already felt like a physical weight. He didn't want to be alone with the echo of the crowd, not now that he knew what this other, quieter feeling was. "Stay. I mean, the rain… it could start again." The excuse was flimsy, and he knew it. He was a terrible liar when it wasn't for a camera.

Leo looked at him, and for a fleeting second, Max thought he saw something in those clear blue eyes—a flicker of understanding, perhaps even a reciprocal curiosity. But it was gone as quickly as it came, replaced by a polite resolve. "I'll be fine. I've worked in worse." He gave a small nod towards the door. "See you on Tuesday."

Max walked him to the door, the vast hallway feeling like a canyon between them. He handed back the damp, fluffy towel, which now seemed like a holy relic. Their fingers brushed as Leo took it, a spark of contact that shot straight up Max’s arm. He snatched his hand back as if burned. Leo didn’t seem to notice, or if he did, he gave no sign. He just offered one last, quiet "Thanks," before pulling the door open and stepping out into the damp, clean-washed air. Max stood in the doorway and watched him walk across the gleaming patio, a solitary figure moving with that same unhurried grace, back to the world where he belonged.

He closed the door, and the expensive, silent latch clicked shut with a deadening finality. The house was his again. His fortress. His tomb. But something had changed. The air was still thick with the scent of rain and soil. A small puddle was evaporating slowly on the limestone floor by the door, and on the marble table sat the empty mug, a testament to the fact that it had all been real. Max walked back into the living room and looked out at the garden. It was no longer just a manicured green space, a feature of the property. It was Leo’s world. A world of patience and growth, of stubborn life and quiet purpose. A world he had just been allowed to glimpse, and one he now desperately, terrifyingly, wanted to be a part of. The tinnitus of the soul was gone, replaced by a low, persistent hum of longing. He had a name for it now. And it was going to change everything.

The weekend was a strange purgatory. On Saturday, Max played. He moved across the pitch with his usual lethal economy of motion, a predator programmed for a single purpose. He scored twice. The first was a technical masterpiece, a volley from an impossible angle that sent the stadium into a frenzy. The second was a simple tap-in, a goal born of instinct and being in the right place at the right time. The crowd chanted his name, the familiar roar washing over him. But this time, it felt like listening to a recording. The sound didn't penetrate; it bounced off a new, inner wall he hadn't known was there. In the locker room, surrounded by the boisterous, back-slapping camaraderie of his teammates, he felt a profound sense of dislocation, as if he were watching a film of his own life. The jokes, the praise, the spray of champagne—it was all happening to someone else, to Max the Brand, while the real Max was standing in a silent, rain-drenched garden.

He spent Sunday replaying not the match, but the quiet moments in his living room. He remembered the exact shade of Leo’s eyes when he’d looked up, surprised, from drying his hair. He remembered the way Leo’s calloused fingers, still traced with soil, had cradled the delicate porcelain of the mug. The memory was more vivid, more vital, than the feeling of the ball hitting the back of the net. He walked through his own house like a stranger, touching the cold surfaces of the marble and glass. He had filled his life with expensive, beautiful, empty things, and it had taken the scent of damp earth and a man who coaxed flowers from the ground to make him see it. The silence was no longer a void, but a canvas. And on it, he could paint only one face, one quiet smile.

The wait for Tuesday was an agony of anticipation. Monday’s training session was a blur. He was physically present, running the drills, taking the shots, but his focus was fractured. His thoughts kept drifting to soil pH and aphid infestations. He was clumsy, his first touch uncharacteristically heavy. His coach, a grizzled veteran named Klaus, pulled him aside, his brow furrowed with concern. "Your head is not in the game, Max. Everything okay?" Max mumbled something about not sleeping well, a plausible lie from a man whose performance was dissected by millions. The lie tasted like ash. All his energy, all the ferocious discipline that had taken him to the top of his profession, was now singularly focused on the passing of hours until he could see his gardener again.

He drove home on Tuesday with a nervous tremor in his hands he usually only felt before a penalty shootout. He saw Leo’s battered blue van parked a few houses down the street and his heart gave a painful thud against his ribs. It was a ridiculous, juvenile reaction, and he hated it and craved it in equal measure. For a moment, he fell back into his old pattern, standing at the panoramic window, watching. Leo was on his knees by the delphiniums, which looked bruised and battered from the storm. He was gently staking the survivors, his movements as tender as a medic on a battlefield. Max watched him for precisely two minutes before the inertia broke. He couldn't just stand there anymore. Being a spectator in his own life was no longer an option. He went to the kitchen, his hands moving with new purpose, and made two cups of coffee.

Walking across the patio, mug in each hand, felt more nerve-wracking than walking out of the tunnel at the Volksparkstadion. The air was cool, carrying the rich, loamy scent of the healing garden. Leo looked up at the sound of his footsteps on the stone. A small, unforced smile touched his lips, and Max felt the tension in his own shoulders ease fractionally. "Come to survey the damage?" Leo asked, his voice calm.

"Something like that," Max said, holding out a mug. "Thought you might need it."

Leo took it, his dirt-smeared fingers brushing against Max’s. The jolt was still there, a low thrum of electricity. "Thank you." He took a sip, his eyes on the wounded flowers. "They took a beating. But they'll live. They're tougher than they look."

They stood in the comfortable silence that Max was coming to cherish, but today he knew he had to fill it. He had to build a bridge, however fragile, across the chasm of their different worlds. He cleared his throat. "I looked up the Etoile de Hollande," he said, the admission feeling monumental. "The rose."

Leo’s head turned fully towards him, his clear blue eyes wide with surprise. The smile he gave this time was different. It was wider, brighter, and it lit up his entire face. "Did you now?" There was an undisguised delight in his voice that made Max’s stomach swoop. "She's a classic. A hybrid tea from 1919. A survivor. Most of the new breeds are all flash, bred for colour and shape, but they've lost their scent. The old ones, they remember that a rose is supposed to smell like a rose." He spoke with such unaffected passion that Max found himself leaning in, desperate to catch every word.

This was his opening, the small gate Leo had just unlocked for him. He had to step through it. "Do you… do you have your own garden?" Max asked, the question feeling both incredibly intimate and deeply inadequate. He wasn't asking about hobbies; he was asking about Leo's life, his home, the place where he wasn't just a man hired to tend to someone else's property. He was asking to be let in.

Leo looked away for a moment, out over the meticulously planned green expanse of Max's garden. A flicker of something complex crossed his face—melancholy, perhaps, or just weariness. "Not like this," he said softly. "I have a small flat in Altona. A balcony. It gets the morning sun." He looked back at Max, and his expression was open, without a trace of envy. "It’s full of pots. Mostly herbs. And a very stubborn tomato plant that seems to think it’s a triffid." He laughed, a quiet, breathy sound. "It's a mess. But it's mine."

A balcony full of pots. A messy, stubborn tomato plant. In that moment, Max would have traded his entire fortress of glass and stone for that small, sun-drenched balcony. He could picture it perfectly: Leo, hands in the soil, a quiet island of purpose in the heart of the bustling city. The image was so painfully lovely, so far removed from Max's own sterile existence, that a wave of longing washed over him so powerful it almost stole his breath. He wanted to see it. He wanted to stand on that balcony, surrounded by a messy jungle of Leo’s creation, and feel the morning sun. The desire was so sharp and clear it felt like a physical need, as urgent and undeniable as the roar of the crowd had ever been.

The words were lodged in his throat, a clumsy, oversized stone he couldn't swallow or spit out. *I want to see it.* The thought was so clear, so loud in his own head, that for a moment he thought he had said it. He looked at Leo, who was still talking about the defiant nature of his tomato plant, and felt a chasm open at his feet. On one side was the safety of his curated silence, the comfortable distance of their employer-employee relationship. On the other was this terrifying, uncharted territory of genuine human connection. He had spent years building walls to keep the world out, and now he was possessed by a desperate urge to ask for an invitation into someone else’s. He took a breath, the air tasting of damp soil and impending rain.

“I’d like to see it,” Max said. The sentence came out quieter than he intended, almost carried away by the breeze. “Your balcony. The tomato plant.” He added the last part as a clumsy anchor, to make it sound like a casual, botanical curiosity rather than what it was: a plea. A raw, unshielded admission of want. He felt the blood rush to his face, a hot tide of self-consciousness. He was certain he had overstepped, that he had shattered the fragile peace they had built. He prepared for the polite refusal, the awkward shift in Leo’s posture, the retreat back into professional distance. He had just risked the only thing that felt real in his life for a messy balcony he had never seen.

Leo went still. He lowered his coffee mug, his gaze leaving the beleaguered delphiniums to fix on Max’s face. The seconds stretched into an eternity, filled only by the rustle of leaves and the distant hum of city traffic. Leo’s blue eyes were unnervingly perceptive, and Max felt stripped bare, as if the man could see straight through the clumsy words to the desperate loneliness beneath. He wasn't looking at Max Richter, the football icon; he was looking at Max, a man standing in his own garden looking utterly lost. Max opened his mouth to take it back, to laugh it off as a joke, but Leo spoke first. His voice was even, devoid of surprise, as if he had been expecting the question all along.

"Okay," he said. Just that single, quiet word. He held Max’s gaze for a moment longer, a silent confirmation, before turning back to his work. The moment of high-stakes tension dissolved, leaving a strange, vibrating calm in its wake. "It's really nothing much. Don't expect a show garden." He picked up a small trowel, his movements resuming their usual fluid rhythm. "I'm free on Sunday morning, if that works for you. Before the city properly wakes up." He named a day, a time, making it real. He wasn't just placating his eccentric boss; he was making a plan. He was opening the door, just a crack.

The rest of the afternoon passed in a dreamlike state. They spoke very little, but the silence was now shot through with a shimmering thread of anticipation. Every rustle of a leaf, every snip of the secateurs, every glance they exchanged was underlined by the promise of Sunday. When Leo finally packed up his tools and headed for the gate, he paused and looked back at Max, who was still standing on the patio. "Sunday, then," he confirmed, and the small smile that accompanied it was a promise. Max watched him leave, and as the gate clicked shut, he felt not the usual descent of quiet emptiness, but the giddy, terrifying ascent of hope. He was alone in his fortress once more, but for the first time, he knew there was a world outside its walls that he might actually be invited into.

The Saturday match was an out-of-body experience. Max played on pure, conditioned reflex, his body a ghost moving through the familiar choreography of the game. He could hear the roar of the crowd, but it was muffled, as if coming from behind a thick pane of glass. His mind was in Altona, on a balcony he’d never seen, wondering what kind of herbs Leo grew and if the tomato plant really was as monstrous as he claimed. He assisted a goal with a perfectly weighted pass, and his teammates mobbed him in celebration, but he felt nothing. The visceral thrill of the game, the drug that had sustained him for over a decade, had lost its potency. There was a new addiction now, a quieter and far more dangerous one.

On Sunday morning, Max woke before his alarm. The sun was a pale wash of silver behind the grey Hamburg clouds. He stood before his vast walk-in closet, a space filled with tailored suits and designer labels, and felt a paralysis he hadn’t experienced since his first professional tryout. Every item felt like a costume for a man he no longer wanted to be. The expensive cashmere sweater was too soft, too privileged. The trendy, artfully distressed jeans were a lie. He was Max the Brand trying to play the part of a regular person. After twenty minutes of agonized indecision, he pulled on a pair of simple, dark jeans he’d owned for years and a plain, soft grey t-shirt. It was the closest he could get to feeling like himself, or at least, the self he hoped to be. He looked in the mirror and saw not a star, but just a man, his eyes bright with a nervousness that was entirely his own.

The drive from Othmarschen to Altona was a journey across invisible borders. He left behind the hushed, tree-lined streets and grand villas for a part of the city that was more tightly woven, more alive. The architecture shifted from minimalist modern to handsome, sturdy pre-war apartment blocks, their facades decorated with the patina of age. Bicycles were chained to railings, the windowsills of upper floors were crowded with plants, and the quiet of his own neighbourhood was replaced by a more human-scaled hum of life. He parked the sleek, black sports car—a vehicle so out of place it felt like an alien spacecraft—and felt a profound sense of being an intruder. He found the building, a handsome Altbau with a clean, tiled entryway, and buzzed the nameplate next to ‘L. Hansen’. A moment later, a click echoed in the stairwell and the heavy door opened. He took a deep breath, the air smelling of old wood and rain-washed pavement, and stepped inside.

### Chapter 2

The stairwell was a cocoon of worn, dark wood and the faint, layered scents of a hundred years of lives lived within its walls. Max climbed the four flights of stairs, his hand trailing on the banister, its polished surface cool and impossibly smooth from the passage of countless hands. With each floor, the sounds and smells shifted—the muffled notes of a piano practice, the aroma of brewing coffee, the quiet murmur of a television. It was a symphony of domesticity, so alien to the echoing silence of his own home that it felt like an artifact from another world. He felt his own expensive, quiet shoes were an intrusion on the creaking floorboards, his presence a disruption of the building's gentle, breathing rhythm.

Leo was waiting at the top of the final flight, his apartment door open. He was leaning against the doorframe, barefoot on the worn wooden threshold, dressed in jeans and a faded, soft-looking band t-shirt that Max didn’t recognise. The sight of him in his own environment, stripped of his work clothes and the context of the garden, was somehow more potent, more real. His hair was damp, as if he’d just showered, and it fell across his brow in the same unruly way. He wasn't smiling, not exactly, but his eyes held a calm, welcoming light.

"You found it," Leo said, his voice softer here, without the open air to carry it. He stepped back, holding the door wider. "Come in."

Max stepped over the threshold and felt as if he had crossed a border into another country. The flat was small, essentially one large, high-ceilinged room with a sleeping loft built over a compact kitchen area. But where Max’s house was a study in expansive emptiness, Leo’s home was a testament to a life fully lived. The walls were lined with overflowing bookshelves, spines ranging from dense botanical textbooks to worn paperbacks of poetry and novels. A vintage record player sat on a low credenza, flanked by stacks of vinyl. An old, comfortable-looking armchair, draped with a knitted blanket, sat angled towards the room’s main feature: a set of tall glass doors that led out onto the balcony, a riot of green pressing up against the panes. The air smelled of coffee, old paper, and the same rich, loamy scent that clung to Leo himself. It wasn’t curated or designed; it was simply a home.

"Wow," Max breathed, the word inadequate for the wave of feeling that washed over him. It was envy, but a strange, hollowed-out kind. He had a house that people photographed for magazines, but he would have traded all of it for the honest, unassuming warmth of this single room.

Leo seemed to misinterpret his reaction, a flicker of self-consciousness crossing his face. "It's a bit… cluttered," he said, running a hand through his hair. "I'm a collector of things. Coffee?"

"Please," Max said, his voice a little hoarse. He watched as Leo moved into the small kitchen space, his movements as economical and graceful as they were in the garden. He retrieved two mismatched ceramic mugs from a hook, the kind of mugs that are acquired over time, each with its own story. Max drifted towards the bookshelves, his fingers ghosting over the spines. He saw names he knew—Rilke, Hesse—and many he didn't. Tucked between a book on soil composition and another on Japanese pruning techniques was a slim, dog-eared volume of Seamus Heaney. He pulled it out, feeling like a spy. The pages fell open to a poem, a line underlined in faint pencil: *Between my finger and my thumb / The squat pen rests; snug as a gun.*

"A gift from my father," Leo's voice said from just behind him, making Max jump slightly. He hadn’t heard him approach. "He was a writer. Always said digging in the dirt and digging for the right word were much the same thing." He handed Max a mug, their fingers brushing for the second time in a week. This time, Max didn't pull away. He let the warmth of the contact linger for a fraction of a second before accepting the mug. The coffee smelled dark and rich.

"He was right," Max said, looking from the book to Leo. He was seeing him in layers now—the gardener, the son of a writer, the man who underlined poetry. Each new piece of information made the feeling in his chest tighten, a sweet, terrifying ache.

Leo gave a small, sad smile. "He had his moments." He gestured with his head towards the glass doors. "Right. The main event. Prepare to be underwhelmed by the famous balcony."

He slid the door open, and the city air, cooler and fresher up here, washed over them. The balcony was exactly as Max had imagined, only more so. It was a glorious, chaotic jungle. Pots of every conceivable size and material were crammed onto the small iron-wrought space, overflowing with life. And there, in pride of place, was the tomato plant. It was a magnificent beast, a sprawling, untamed entity that had wound its way up the railing and was now making a bid for the roof, its vines heavy with clusters of green and blushing-red fruit. All around it were herbs—a woody, fragrant rosemary bush, plumes of dill, a cascade of mint, and the sharp, clean scent of basil. Bees hummed contentedly around a pot of lavender that looked strikingly similar to the 'arrogant' patch in Max’s own garden.

"It's incredible," Max said, stepping out into the green chaos. He was surrounded. In his garden, nature was something to be viewed from a distance, framed by a window. Here, he was in it, a part of it. He reached out and gently touched a leaf on the tomato plant. It felt slightly fuzzy, alive. "You called this a mess?"

"It is a mess," Leo replied, a note of fond exasperation in his voice. "It has no sense of order. Everything just grows where it wants. I just try to keep it from taking over the neighbour's balcony." He leaned against the railing, looking out over the view. There was no sprawling lawn, no ancient trees. The view was of rooftops, of brick walls and other windows, a patchwork quilt of urban life. Yet, from this small, green oasis, it looked like the most beautiful landscape in the world. "This is it. My little patch of dirt in the sky."

Max stood beside him, their shoulders almost touching. The space was so small, so intimate. He could smell the coffee on Leo's breath, see the faint lines around his eyes left by sun and smiling. The roar of the stadium felt like a memory from a past life. The pressure, the headlines, the constant, grinding weight of being Max Richter—it all dissolved up here, in the quiet morning air, surrounded by a stubborn tomato plant and the man who tended it. He had come here to see a balcony, but what he had found was a glimpse of a life he didn't know he was starving for. He wanted to stay in this small, cluttered, beautiful world forever.

### Chapter 3

They stood in the quiet hum of the city morning, suspended four storeys high in Leo’s green sanctuary. The silence that settled between them was different from the comfortable quiet of the garden; it was charged, close, and felt breathable. Max was acutely aware of the smallness of the space, of the way Leo’s arm brushed his when he shifted his weight. He was an intruder, a tourist in this world, yet he had never felt more at home. He wanted to say something, anything to anchor the moment, to explain the tectonic shift happening inside him, but his tongue felt thick and useless. His entire vocabulary of desire was tied to victory, to conquest, to the roar of a crowd. It had no words for this gentle, unfolding peace.

As if sensing Max’s internal paralysis, Leo broke the spell. He turned from the rooftop vista and reached into the glorious tangle of the tomato plant. His movements were sure, his fingers tracing a vine until they found what they were looking for. He plucked a single, small tomato, a perfect globe of crimson so vibrant it seemed to pulse with its own light. Without a word, he held it out to Max, resting in the centre of his palm, an offering. The lines on his hand were etched with soil, a map of his labour. It was the simplest of gestures, yet it felt more profound than any trophy Max had ever lifted. Hesitantly, Max took it. The skin was warm from the morning sun, taut and smooth beneath his thumb.

“They taste better when you eat them right away,” Leo said softly, his eyes watching Max’s face with an open curiosity. Max raised the small fruit to his lips. The moment it broke against his teeth, his senses were flooded. It was an explosion of flavour—a sharp, sun-drenched sweetness balanced by a clean, earthy acidity. It was nothing like the perfectly uniform, perfectly tasteless tomatoes he found in his state-of-the-art refrigerator. This tasted of soil and sky and patience. It tasted real. He closed his eyes for a second, savouring the sensation, a ghost of a flavour he’d forgotten from a childhood that felt a lifetime away.

"I don't think I've ever really tasted a tomato before," Max confessed, the words raw and honest. He looked at Leo, feeling stripped bare. "Everything in my life... it's sourced from somewhere else. Grown for travel, not for taste. It all looks perfect, but there's nothing there." The admission hung in the air between them, a confession not just about fruit, but about everything: the house, the car, the career. His life was a hothouse flower, beautiful and sterile.

Leo didn't offer pity or platitudes. He just nodded, his gaze steady and understanding. He picked a sprig of basil, crushed a leaf gently between his thumb and forefinger, and held it out for Max to smell. The sharp, peppery scent filled the air. "Things need a bit of a struggle," Leo said, his voice thoughtful. "The wind makes the stems stronger. A dry spell makes the roots dig deeper. You can’t get flavour without a little bit of stress. Perfect conditions just make for boring plants." He looked from the sprawling, chaotic life on his balcony to Max’s face, and Max knew, with absolute certainty, that they were no longer talking about gardening.

The spell of the morning couldn't last forever. The city below was waking up, its hum growing into a more insistent thrum. Max knew he had to leave, to return to the world where he belonged, even if it felt like a foreign country. The thought of descending the stairs and getting back into his soulless, powerful car felt like an act of profound self-betrayal. "I should go," he said, the words feeling like stones in his mouth.

He followed Leo back into the apartment, which now seemed even more inviting, a haven of warmth and substance. At the door, the awkwardness of their first meetings had completely vanished, replaced by a new, undefined intimacy. "Thank you for the coffee," Max said. "And the tomato."

"Any time," Leo replied, and the simple phrase held a universe of meaning. He leaned against the doorframe, that same casual posture from when Max had arrived, but his eyes held a new warmth. "Drive safe, Max." The use of his first name, spoken so naturally in the quiet of the stairwell, was a final, gentle click of a lock falling into place. It was a recognition. Not of the star, but of the man.

The drive back to Othmarschen was surreal. Max saw his neighbourhood through new eyes. The manicured lawns, the high walls, the pristine, silent streets—it all seemed like a carefully constructed set, a beautiful but lifeless diorama. When he pulled into his own driveway, the house loomed before him, a monument of glass and white stone, and for the first time, he felt a deep, abiding resentment for it. It was his prize and his prison. He walked inside, and the silence that greeted him was no longer funereal; it was accusatory. He stood in the centre of his minimalist living room and looked at his hands, clean, unmarked, and utterly useless. The ghost of a real tomato was still on his tongue, a reminder of a world where things were allowed to be beautifully, imperfectly alive.

Tuesday came. Max didn't go to the window. He didn't pace the patio with a glass of water. He woke up, bypassed his wardrobe of costumes, and pulled on the same jeans and t-shirt he had worn to Altona. In the large, sterile utility room, he found a pair of stiff, new gardening gloves he must have bought on the same day he'd hired the landscaping company, a forgotten prop for a role he never intended to play. He pulled them on, the leather creaking in protest, and walked outside into the cool morning air. Leo was already there, kneeling by a bed of anemones, his back to the house.

Max walked across the dew-wet grass, his footsteps quiet. He stopped a few feet away from where Leo was working. "Leo," he said. Leo looked up, startled, his hand frozen in the act of pulling a weed. Surprise flickered across his face, followed by a slow, questioning smile as he took in Max's attire and the ridiculous, pristine gloves. "I… I want to help," Max said, the words coming out more firmly than he expected. He held up his gloved hands, a gesture of both surrender and intent. "Show me what to do."

For a moment, Leo just stared, his blue eyes searching Max’s. Then, the corner of his mouth twitched, and the questioning smile bloomed into something genuine and wide and wonderful. A quiet laugh escaped him, a sound of pure, unadulterated delight that made the garden feel ten times brighter. He patted the patch of soft earth beside him. "Okay," he said, his voice laced with amusement and something else, something warm and welcoming. "First lesson: you have to learn the difference between a weed and a thousand-euro peony seedling. The stakes are a little higher here than with a tomato plant." Max knelt down on the damp ground, the unfamiliar position awkward but right. The world of the garden closed in around him, and for the first time, he was not just looking at it. He was in it, his hands in the same soil, ready to learn.

The new gloves felt alien and absurd, a layer of stiff, sterile leather between him and the world he so desperately wanted to touch. Kneeling felt unnatural, a posture of supplication his body, honed for aggression and dominance, had almost forgotten. He felt like a child playing dress-up, clumsy and oversized in this delicate, intricate world. The ground was cool and damp through the knees of his jeans, an immediate, grounding sensation. Beside him, Leo worked with an effortless economy of motion, his bare hands discerning and decisive. He pulled a slender green shoot with a gentle tug, exposing a network of thin white roots. He held it up for Max's inspection.

"This is chickweed," Leo explained, his voice low and instructive. "Feels soft, almost flimsy. See how it creates a mat? It'll steal water from the surface before it can get down to the deeper roots of the plants you actually want. It's not evil, just greedy." He tossed it onto a growing pile. "Now, look here." He pointed to a small, clover-like sprout right next to it. "This looks similar, but feel the stem. It's tougher. And see the leaves? This is a columbine seedling. A volunteer. She decided she wanted to grow here. So we let her." It was a whole new language, a complex grammar of leaf shapes, textures, and intentions. Max looked at the patch of earth before him, which had once been a simple, undifferentiated patch of green, and now saw a battlefield of competing desires, a community of allies and rivals.

Max’s first attempts were hesitant and brutish. His hands, trained to grip and throw and exert force, struggled with the required delicacy. He yanked a stubborn thistle and it came away with a huge clump of soil, terrifyingly close to the roots of a fragile-looking fern. Leo made a soft, placating sound. "Easy," he said, not with criticism, but with the same gentle encouragement he might use on a spooked animal. "Don't fight it. Feel for where the root is thickest, right at the base. Loosen the soil around it first. Persuade it to let go." He placed his hand over Max's, the rough warmth of his skin seeping through the new leather of the glove. He guided Max's fingers to the base of another weed, showing him how to apply pressure, how to rock it back and forth. The touch was brief, instructional, and yet it sent a tremor through Max’s entire system. Under Leo’s guidance, the weed came free with a satisfying pop, leaving the surrounding soil almost undisturbed. Max stared at the void in the earth, his heart hammering.

They worked like that for what felt like hours, moving slowly along the flowerbed. The sun warmed Max’s back, and a light sweat broke out on his brow. His knees began to ache, a dull, unfamiliar complaint. His back, conditioned for the explosive torque of a volley, protested the sustained, hunched-over posture. It was humbling, punishing work. Yet, with every weed he correctly identified and removed, with every inch of soil he cleared, a quiet sense of satisfaction began to build. It was a completely different feeling from the adrenaline-fueled ecstasy of a goal. That was a fleeting, explosive high that left him hollowed out. This was a slow, cumulative contentment, a feeling of having brought a tiny pocket of the world into a better order. He was not performing for anyone. The only audience was Leo, and the judgment in his eyes was not of success or failure, but of effort and intention.

Later, they moved to the "Etoile de Hollande," the crimson rose that had served as their first bridge. Its initial burst of blooms had faded, the petals beginning to brown and curl at the edges. "Time to deadhead," Leo announced, handing Max a pair of sharp, clean secateurs. The tool felt weighty and purposeful in his hand. "You have to cut away the old flowers. If you let them go to seed, the plant thinks its job is done for the year. It gets lazy. But if you cut them back," he pointed to a joint in the stem, just above a set of five leaves, "it tells her, 'Not yet. There's still more to do.' It encourages a whole new flush of blooms." He looked at Max, his blue eyes direct. "Sometimes you have to cut away the dying parts to make room for new life."

Max took a deep breath, the metaphor landing with the force of a physical blow. He reached for a withered bloom, the secateurs feeling like a surgical instrument. He found the five-leaf junction Leo had shown him, the point of new potential. He made the cut. The crisp snip of the blades was a sound of finality and promise. The dead flower fell to the ground. He moved to the next, and the next, a rhythm building between them. Leo worked on the other side of the bush, their movements creating a quiet, collaborative dance. They weren’t talking much, but the air was thick with unspoken communication. They were tending to more than just a rose bush. They were pruning away the old silence, the distance, making way for whatever new and fragile thing was determined to grow between them.

When the sun began to dip lower, casting long shadows across the lawn, Leo finally straightened up, stretching his back with a soft groan. He began to gather his tools, wiping the soil from them with a worn rag. The day was over. The familiar pang of anticipatory loss hit Max, but it was different this time, blunted by the shared hours and the satisfying ache in his muscles. He didn't want Leo to leave, but he also knew he would be back on Friday, and the dynamic had irrevocably shifted. "Let me help," Max said, surprising himself. He gestured to the tools. "I can clean them."

Leo paused, looking at Max's dirt-streaked face, his hair dishevelled from the work. He looked at the expensive, ridiculous gloves, now scuffed and stained with earth. A slow, genuine smile spread across his face, reaching his eyes and making them crinkle. "Okay, Max," he said, and the way he said his name was different, imbued with a new familiarity, a shared experience. He handed Max the rag and the trowel. In the cool evening air, they stood side-by-side on the stone patio, cleaning the tools of their trade. As Max worked the dirt from the blade of the trowel, he noticed the soil lodged deep under his own fingernails, a dark crescent of proof. The stadium and its roar were a distant echo from another man's life. This, he thought, wiping the blade clean. This is real.

### Chapter 4

After Leo left, Max remained on the patio, watching the evening light bleed out of the sky. The trowel in his hand was still cool, the cleaned metal gleaming faintly. He was alone, but the silence wasn't empty. It was filled with the residue of a shared day, the echo of quiet instruction and easy laughter. He looked down at his hands. Even after washing them at the outdoor tap, a faint line of rich, dark earth remained stubbornly lodged beneath each fingernail. He held them up, studying them in the fading light. They looked like a stranger’s hands, or rather, like the hands of a man he was only just beginning to meet. He felt a deep, unfamiliar ache in his lower back and a pleasant burn in his thighs from hours of kneeling. It was the pain of effort, not injury, and it felt like a badge of honour. He walked back into his silent, minimalist fortress, and for the first time, he didn't feel like a ghost haunting its halls. He had brought the garden inside with him, on his clothes, under his nails, in the very marrow of his bones.

The change in him was subtle at first, a slight shift in his orbit that only those closest to the centre could detect. At training, he was still focused, still lethally effective, but the fierce, almost desperate intensity that had always defined him was tempered with a new calm. In the locker room, he found himself drifting away from the loud post-mortems of the game, the endless talk of cars and contracts. He would sit on the bench, stretching out his sore back, his mind miles away, contemplating the ongoing war against aphids or the precise angle needed to prune a climbing rose. Klaus, his coach, watched him with a shrewd, calculating eye. "You're playing with your head up, Richter," he’d grunted after one session, a high compliment from the taciturn man. "Seeing the whole field. Good. Whatever you're doing, keep doing it." Max had just nodded, unsure how to explain that he was learning to see the whole field by focusing on a single square meter of dirt.

His agent, a perpetually frantic man named Fischer, was less impressed. Fischer lived and breathed the brand of Max Richter, a carefully constructed edifice of success, discipline, and marketable aloofness. He called on Wednesday, his voice vibrating with excitement over a "synergistic multi-platform opportunity" involving a new luxury watch and a reality TV special about the lives of elite athletes. It was the kind of deal that would have once been the centrepiece of Max’s financial planning for the year. He listened patiently to Fischer's breathless pitch, picturing Leo on his balcony, coaxing life from a pot of soil. The disconnect was so vast, so utterly absurd, that he almost laughed. “No,” Max said, when Fischer finally paused for air.

There was a stunned silence on the other end of the line. "No? What do you mean, no? Max, this is the campaign of the year. We’ve been chasing this for months."

"I'm not interested, Fischer. I'm… busy," Max said, the excuse sounding feeble even to his own ears.

"Busy? The season doesn’t start for another two weeks! Busy with what?" Fischer’s voice was rising, a thin wire of panic stretching tight. Max looked at his hands, at the faint trace of earth he hadn’t managed to scrub away. "I'm working on a project," he said simply. "A personal one." He ended the call, ignoring Fischer’s sputtering protests, and felt a profound sense of relief. He had cut away a dying flower, and the sound of the snip was the most satisfying thing he’d heard all day.

He spent the next day and a half in a state of quiet anticipation. He bought books—not just glossy coffee table volumes, but serious, dense horticultural texts. He sat in his vast, empty living room and read about soil composition, about nitrogen cycles and companion planting. He learned the Latin names for the plants in his garden, rolling the strange, ancient words around in his mouth. *Digitalis purpurea*. *Hydrangea macrophylla*. It was like learning a secret code, the key to a world that had been hidden from him in plain sight. He was no longer waiting to see Leo; he was waiting to get back to work.

When Friday arrived, he was already outside when Leo’s van pulled up. He was wearing an old t-shirt and jeans, the ridiculous new gloves already discarded in a corner of the shed. He was on his knees, attempting to clear the tangled roots of some invasive ground ivy from the base of the silver birch. Leo walked across the lawn, a small, amused smile playing on his lips. "Eager, are we?" he asked, setting his tool bag down on the grass. "The ivy is a battle of attrition. You won't win in a day."

"I'm just softening up the enemy," Max replied, not looking up from his work. He could feel Leo's presence settle beside him, a familiar and welcome weight. They fell into an easy rhythm, working in comfortable silence for a while, their shared purpose a conversation in itself. The sun was warm, and the air was sweet with the scent of cut grass from a neighbouring garden. It was Max who spoke first, his question uncharacteristically direct. "That t-shirt you were wearing. On Sunday. What was the band?"

Leo paused, a fistful of ivy in his hand. He looked at Max, a flicker of surprise in his eyes. "The National," he said. "They write sad songs about Midwestern ennui. It's more cheerful than it sounds."

"Right," Max said, though he had no idea what that meant. "And your father… the writer. What did he write?"

The question hung in the air for a moment. Leo’s smile faded slightly, replaced by a more thoughtful, distant expression. "Poems, mostly. A few essays. Nothing famous. He taught literature at the university to pay the bills. He saw poetry everywhere. In the rhythm of a bricklayer's trowel, in the way rust bloomed on an old fence." He looked down at his own hands, turning them over. "He used to say I was the only poem he ever managed to get right." The confession was quiet, intensely personal, and it landed in the space between them with a gentle weight. Max felt a sudden, fierce protectiveness, a desire to shield this man from the memory of whatever sadness lingered behind his words.

They worked until the shadows grew long and the tools were cleaned and put away. They stood on the patio, drinking tall glasses of cold water, both of them streaked with dirt and sweat, tired and content. The usual pre-departure quiet began to settle, but this time Max refused to let it take hold. He had spent his life reacting, letting the game, the media, the agents, dictate his next move. Now, for the first time, he was going to be the one to set the play in motion. "I'm hungry," he said, his voice steadier than he felt. "Are you?" He looked directly at Leo, holding his gaze. "Let me buy you dinner. As a thank you for the lessons. Not here," he added quickly, gesturing at the glass fortress behind him. "Somewhere else. Somewhere normal. In Altona, maybe."

Leo went very still. He lowered his glass, his blue eyes searching Max's face, trying to read the intention behind the invitation. It was a clear and unambiguous crossing of a line, a step out of the carefully defined roles of their Tuesdays and Fridays and into something unknown. Max held his breath, his heart hammering a frantic rhythm against his ribs. It was more terrifying than taking a penalty in a World Cup final. He saw a flicker of hesitation in Leo's eyes, a shadow of uncertainty, and his hope faltered. But then, Leo's expression softened, the caution giving way to a slow, dawning smile. He gave a small, almost imperceptible nod. "Okay, Max," he said, his voice quiet but clear. "Okay."

The drive to Altona that evening was a journey into a different state of being. Max changed his clothes three times, cycling through the limited selection of his "normal" attire, feeling like a fraud in each outfit. He was dressing for a role he didn't know how to play: just a man having dinner. He eventually settled on a dark, unremarkable sweater and the same jeans he had worn in the garden, hoping they would act as a passport into Leo's world. Driving his low-slung, aggressively expensive car through the vibrant, narrow streets felt like steering a shark through a goldfish pond. He parked several blocks away from their meeting point, the car's silent alarm chirping like an anxious bird, and walked the rest of the way, feeling the city's living pulse through the soles of his shoes.

The place Leo had chosen was a small, bustling trattoria tucked into a side street, its windows fogged with warmth and condensation. The name was painted in simple script on the glass: *La Lanterna*. Inside, the air was thick with the scent of garlic, baked bread, and red wine. It was noisy, filled with the clatter of cutlery and the overlapping chatter of families and couples. It was the absolute antithesis of the hushed, cavernous restaurants where his agent took him to close deals. Leo was already there, seated at a small wooden table in the corner, nursing a glass of water. He looked up as Max approached, and the smile he offered was so natural, so completely at ease in this environment, that Max’s own coiled-spring tension eased by a crucial notch. In this world, Leo was the host, and Max, for once, was simply the guest.

They fell into an initially stilted conversation, the kind that happens when a relationship is transitioning from one context to another. They talked about the wine list, the specials scribbled on a chalkboard, the surprisingly mild weather. Max was hyper-aware of his surroundings, convinced every glance in their direction was one of recognition, but no one seemed to pay him any mind. He was just another face in the crowd, a novel and slightly unsettling sensation. The food arrived—hearty, unpretentious plates of pasta that steamed up between them—and with it, a new level of comfort. It was Max who finally breached the divide, pushing a stray noodle around his plate. "The tomato you gave me," he began, his voice lower than the restaurant's din. "That's what this tastes like. Real."

Leo looked up from his meal, his expression serious. "That's why I like this place," he said. "The owner, Gianni, his family has a small farm outside Naples. He imports his own tomatoes. He says you can't rush flavour." Leo took a sip of his wine, his gaze thoughtful. "It's a lesson that's hard to learn in a city. Everything is about speed, efficiency. Getting to the next thing. My father... he always said I was lucky. That my work forced me into a different rhythm. You can’t tell a seed to hurry up." He paused, setting his glass down. "I think that's why I could never do what he did. Staring at a blank page. The pressure of creating something from nothing… it’s too much like a penalty kick."

The casual, unexpected mention of his world, woven so seamlessly into a conversation about tomatoes and poetry, caught Max completely off guard. It wasn't fawning or star-struck; it was just an observation, a point of connection. "It is," Max admitted, a knot of tension he hadn't known he was carrying suddenly loosening. "That's exactly what it's like. The whole world goes silent, and it's just you, and the ball, and a thousand ways to fail." He had never articulated it that way to anyone, not to a coach, not to a teammate, not to a journalist. He had never had the words, or the trust. He looked at Leo, at the quiet intelligence in his eyes, and felt a sudden, reckless urge to tell him everything.

As the evening wore on, the restaurant thinned out, and their conversation deepened, meandering from the merits of different kinds of soil to the sad, beautiful songs of The National. They discovered a shared, surprising love for old black-and-white films. Leo talked about how his mother taught him the names of birds, and Max found himself speaking about his own childhood, about kicking a worn leather ball against a garage door in a quiet suburb, a memory he hadn't revisited in years. At some point, a young man at the bar, no older than twenty, did a double-take. He whispered to his friend, pointing discreetly. Max felt the familiar tightening in his gut, the bracing for the inevitable interruption. But Leo, without missing a beat in the story he was telling, subtly shifted in his chair, turning his shoulder slightly to create a small, almost imperceptible screen. He leaned forward, his voice dropping conspiratorially. "The real trick to hydrangeas," he said, drawing Max's focus completely, "is rusty nails. They love the iron." The intensity of his gaze held Max captive, and by the time Max looked back towards the bar, the moment had passed. The young man had turned away, apparently deciding he was mistaken. Max looked back at Leo, whose expression was perfectly neutral, but there was a knowing glint in his eyes. The quiet, effortless act of protection was more intimate than any touch.

They were among the last to leave. The cool night air was a welcome shock after the warmth of the trattoria. They walked in a comfortable silence through the now-quiet streets towards Leo’s building. The city felt soft and muted, their footsteps echoing slightly on the pavement. At the heavy wooden door to his apartment block, they stopped. The streetlights cast a warm, golden glow, creating a small, private stage. "Thank you for dinner, Max," Leo said. "And for… not making it weird." He offered a small, crooked smile. "I half-expected you to have a security detail hiding behind a potted plant."

Max laughed, a real, unburdened sound. "The night is young. They might still be in the stairwell." The joke fell easily between them. The moment stretched, full of unspoken things. He should go. He should say goodnight and walk back to his spaceship of a car and return to his planet. But his feet were rooted to the spot. "I had a really good time, Leo," he said, and the simple, honest words felt more significant than any post-match interview he’d ever given.

"Me too," Leo replied, his voice soft. He reached out and, for just a second, rested his hand on Max’s arm. The warmth of his touch spread through the fabric of Max's sweater, a steady, grounding heat. It wasn't a handshake or a pat; it was a connection. "I'll see you on Tuesday," he said, before turning and disappearing into the dark maw of the building, the heavy door clicking shut behind him. Max stood there for a long moment, the feeling of Leo's hand still lingering on his arm, a phantom limb. He walked back to his car, the echo of the crowd finally, blessedly, silent. It had been replaced by the memory of a quiet voice talking about rusty nails and the ghost of a warm, certain touch. He was falling, and for the first time in his life, he had no interest in stopping the fall.

### Chapter 5

The days between Friday night and Tuesday morning were a new kind of purgatory for Max. He played a match on Sunday, a crucial pre-season friendly. He was a phantom on the pitch, his body executing its finely-tuned commands with a chilling detachment. He scored the winning goal in the final minutes, a powerful header that sent the stadium into its customary paroxysm of joy. As his teammates buried him in a celebratory pile-on, their shouts of triumph muffled against his ear, all he could feel was the ghost of Leo’s hand on his arm, a quiet anchor in a roaring sea. The roar was no longer a drug; it was just noise. The victory was no longer a conquest; it was just the end of the game, a signal that he was one step closer to Tuesday. He retreated into his fortress of glass and stone, but now its silence felt less like an absence and more like a waiting room, a space pregnant with the possibility of a life he was finally, tentatively, choosing.

When Tuesday arrived, the garden felt electric. The air, usually just a neutral medium for sound and scent, now seemed to hum with a low-frequency charge. Max was already outside, kneeling by the unruly lavender bush, when Leo arrived. He didn't turn around, but he felt the exact moment Leo’s presence settled on the lawn, a subtle shift in the atmosphere. Leo walked over and set his tools down without a word, kneeling beside him. The unspoken was a third presence between them—the memory of the trattoria, the flickering candlelight, the shared wine, the effortless intimacy of their conversation. They were no longer employer and employee, not even just teacher and student. They were two people who had shared a meal, who knew the other’s taste in film, who had glimpsed the private architecture of each other’s lives.

"She’s getting leggy," Leo said, his voice a low murmur that was for Max alone. He gestured to the lavender. "She needs a hard prune after she flowers, or she’ll get woody and split at the base." Max nodded, reaching for the shears. "I read that a mulch of shingle can help with drainage and reflect heat back up into the plant. They like their feet dry." Leo stopped, his hand halfway to a stray weed, and looked at Max. A slow, deeply amused smile spread across his face, lighting up his eyes. "You've been studying," he stated, a hint of wonder in his tone. "I'm going to be out of a job soon." The shared joke was easy, a comfortable shorthand. "Not a chance," Max replied, the corner of his own mouth turning up. "I still can't tell a peony from a thistle half the time."

They worked in a tandem rhythm, their hands often moving in the same small patch of soil. The casual, accidental brushes of their arms and shoulders were no longer electric shocks, but quiet affirmations of their proximity. The air between them was charged but no longer tense. Just before noon, Max's phone, which he'd left on the patio table, began to buzz insistently. The name on the screen was FISCHER. Max felt his jaw tighten. He walked over and answered, turning his back to the garden in a futile attempt at privacy. "What is it, Fischer?" His voice was clipped. He listened for a moment, his posture growing rigid as his agent’s frantic, high-pitched voice spilled through the receiver. Leo continued to weed, his movements deliberate, but Max knew he could hear. "No," Max said firmly. "No, I am not flying to Milan for a watch fitting. I told you, I have other commitments... Because they are important to me... No, they are not negotiable." He took a breath, trying to rein in his frustration. "Fischer, listen to me. Cancel it. I don't care about the penalty clause. Just handle it." He ended the call without waiting for a reply, the silence that followed deafening.

He stood for a long moment, his back to Leo, his knuckles white as he gripped the phone. He felt exposed, the ugly machinery of his life laid bare. He had tried so hard to keep this world separate from the one he was building here, but the walls were proving to be porous. He finally turned around to face Leo, a tight, apologetic knot in his stomach. Leo was watching him, his expression unreadable. He wasn't pretending he hadn't heard. After a beat, he spoke, his voice quiet and even. "Is it always like that?" The question was simple, devoid of judgment or morbid curiosity. It was an offer. Max let out a breath he didn't realize he'd been holding. "Yes," he said, the single word carrying the weight of a decade of suffocating pressure. "Or worse. They don't see a person. They see a brand. An asset. They schedule every minute. What I wear, what I say, where I'm seen. They want to own all the parts of me." He looked away, out over the green expanse that Leo had brought back to life. "This," he gestured to the soil on his hands, the garden around them, "is the only part they don't know about. The only part that's just mine."

The confession hung in the afternoon air, a fragile and precious thing. Leo held it with a gentle reverence. He didn’t offer sympathy or advice. He simply nodded, his eyes full of a deep, quiet understanding that went beyond words. He stood up and walked over to Max, stopping just in front of him. "Then we should make the most of it," he said softly. The simple statement was an act of allegiance, a drawing of a line in the sand. He was on Max's side. The rest of the afternoon passed in a haze of heightened awareness. The work was the same, but the context had changed. They were no longer just tending a garden; they were carving out a sanctuary, a secret territory that belonged only to them.

As the sun began its descent, painting the sky in strokes of orange and violet, they cleaned the tools together on the patio. The familiar end-of-day ritual was imbued with a new poignancy. Max knew, with a certainty that was both terrifying and exhilarating, that he could not let Leo walk away. He could not go back inside his silent house and pretend that this was enough. He placed the trowel he was cleaning carefully on the stone ledge. "Leo." His voice was hoarse. Leo looked up from the secateurs he was wiping, his brow furrowed slightly at the tone. Max took a half-step closer, closing the distance between them until he could feel the warmth radiating from Leo's body. The air grew thick, heavy with unspoken words. "This," Max said, his voice barely a whisper. He gestured with his hand in the small space between them, a gesture that encompassed the dirt on their clothes, the fading light, the quiet of the garden. "This is the only thing that feels real anymore."

It was not a question. It was a statement of fact, the truest thing he had ever said. Leo's eyes, a clear and startling blue, searched his face, reading the layers of fear and desperate hope laid bare there. For a heart-stopping second, Max saw a flicker of panic in their depths, and he thought he had shattered everything. But it was followed by a wave of something else, a profound and yielding softness. Leo’s gaze dropped to Max’s lips, and in that tiny movement, the world tilted on its axis. He didn't speak. He didn't have to. He took the final, small step that closed the last inch of space between them. The first touch of their lips was unimaginably soft, a hesitant, questioning pressure. It was not a kiss of conquest or of frantic, pent-up passion. It was a kiss of recognition, a slow, deep discovery. It tasted of earth, and sunlight, and the sweet, agonizing relief of a man who had been lost for a very long time finally, finally finding his way home.

When the kiss ended, it was not with a sharp parting but a slow, reluctant easing of pressure, a gradual return to the world. Max kept his eyes closed for a second longer, trying to imprint the sensation into his memory, a new taste to replace the metallic tang of adrenaline that had been the flavour of his life. He could smell the lavender from the nearby bush, the damp earth, and the clean, warm scent of Leo’s skin. When he finally opened his eyes, Leo was still there, impossibly close, his forehead resting lightly against Max’s. His blue eyes were dark in the twilight, his expression one of profound, searching seriousness. The world had shrunk to the space between their faces.

It was Leo who spoke first, his voice a low, rough murmur that was felt as much as it was heard. "So that's what that was," he said, not as a question, but as a quiet, dawning realisation. He raised a hand, his calloused thumb coming up to gently trace the line of Max’s jaw, a gesture of such startling, simple tenderness that Max felt his knees weaken. He had been held aloft by stadiums, tackled by the strongest defenders in the world, but he had never felt a touch so grounding, so utterly solid. All the air went out of Max’s lungs in a quiet rush, taking with it the last vestiges of the phantom roar. In its place, there was only the steady, rhythmic beat of his own heart, finally in time with something real.

"I think I'm falling in love with you," Max heard himself say, the words tumbling out, clumsy and unadorned, stripped of all artifice. It was the most terrifying and liberating sentence he had ever spoken. He had expected Leo to flinch, to pull back from the raw, unshielded weight of the confession. Instead, a slow, gentle smile touched Leo’s lips, a smile of pure, unadulterated relief. "I think," Leo said, his thumb coming to rest on Max's lower lip, "you're a little late. I've been halfway there since you asked me about the rose." The honesty of it, the simple, reciprocal truth, was a balm on a wound Max hadn't known was still open. He leaned in and kissed him again, a second kiss that was no longer a discovery, but a confirmation. It was deeper, more certain, a silent conversation in which everything that needed to be said was understood.

The sky had deepened to a bruised purple when they finally drew apart, the first stars beginning to prick the darkness. The reality of the moment began to settle in. Leo was still holding his tools. Max was still in his work clothes. This was a Tuesday. "You should go," Max said, though the words felt like a betrayal. "It's late. You have to drive home." He hated the thought of Leo leaving, of this perfect, suspended moment ending, but he also felt a fierce, protective need for Leo to be safe, to be home. The desire to take care of him was a novel and powerful instinct.

Leo looked towards his van parked down the street, then back at Max. "Or," he said slowly, a playful, daring light entering his eyes, "I could stay." He gestured vaguely towards the glass fortress behind them. "You did offer me tea once. I'm sure you could manage dinner. Unless, of course, your personal project commitments are all booked up." The gentle teasing was a gift, a normalisation of the impossible thing that had just happened. It made it real, tangible, something that could exist beyond this one perfect evening in the garden. Max felt a laugh bubble up, a sound so full of joy it startled him. "My schedule," he said, taking Leo's hand and lacing their fingers together, the fit of their palms, one calloused and strong, the other smooth and trained, feeling preordained and perfect, "has just been cleared. Indefinitely."

He led Leo inside, not as a guest this time, but as an integral part of the space. The house, which had always felt like a sterile gallery, was transformed by his presence. The vast, silent rooms seemed to shrink, to become warmer and more intimate. Leo stood in the kitchen, a cathedral of stainless steel and white marble he had only glimpsed before, and looked completely at home, leaning against a counter as Max, with a novice’s uncertainty, began pulling ingredients from the refrigerator. They made pasta, a simple, messy affair full of laughter and flour on the floor and too much garlic. They ate not at the cavernous dining table built for twelve, but sitting on stools at the kitchen island, their knees bumping together, the house filled with the sounds of conversation and the clinking of forks against plates. For the first time, Max was not just inhabiting his house; he was living in it.

Later, they sat on the minimalist sofa where Leo had shivered in his wet clothes weeks before. He showed Max pictures on his phone of the "triffid" tomato plant at various stages of its defiant growth, and of a small, scruffy dog he had once fostered. Max, in turn, found himself telling Leo stories from his early career, not the polished anecdotes for the press, but the real ones—the homesickness, the loneliness of hotel rooms, the crushing fear of not being good enough. Leo listened, his head resting on Max's shoulder, his quiet presence a safe harbour for all the things Max had never known how to say. The storm that Max had felt inside him that rainy afternoon had finally passed, leaving behind a profound and peaceful calm. He was no longer falling. He had landed. And in the quiet warmth of his once-empty house, surrounded by the scent of garlic and damp earth and the steady breathing of the man beside him, he knew, with a certainty that settled deep in his bones, that he was finally, irrevocably, home.

### Chapter 6

Max woke to the unfamiliar sensation of sunlight. He had blackout blinds, automated and absolute, that sealed his bedroom in a tomb of perfect darkness every night. But this morning, a thin, defiant sliver of gold cut across the far wall. Leo had opened them, just a crack. The world had been let in. The other side of the vast bed was empty, but the pillow held the impression of his head and the faint, clean scent of his skin. For a moment, Max lay perfectly still, disoriented. The silence of the house was different, not the sterile, echoing quiet he was used to, but a softer silence, punctuated by a distant, gentle clinking from downstairs. It was the sound of life. He got out of bed, forgoing his usual silk robe for a pair of shorts, and padded barefoot out of the room, his footsteps silent on the cool stone floor.

He found Leo in the kitchen, standing with his back to him, looking out the panoramic window at the garden. He was wearing a pair of Max’s grey sweatpants, cinched at the waist, and an old t-shirt Max hadn't worn in years. He held a mug in his hands and was perfectly still, just watching the morning light spill over the lawn. The sight was so profoundly domestic, so breathtakingly normal, that it stole the air from Max’s lungs. This man, who had entered his life as a shape in the garden, was now a fixture in his kitchen, wearing his clothes, watching over their shared patch of earth. Leo seemed to sense him and turned, a slow, sleepy smile spreading across his face. It was a smile without artifice or agenda, a simple expression of contentment. "Morning," he said, his voice still rough with sleep. "I made coffee. I hope you don't mind. I couldn't figure out your spaceship of a machine, so I just used the French press I found in the back of the cupboard."

That French press had been a housewarming gift, relegated to a dusty corner, an analog relic in a digital world. "It's perfect," Max said, his voice thick. He crossed the kitchen and took the mug Leo offered him. Their fingers brushed, and the simple touch was an anchor, a confirmation that the night had been real. They stood side-by-side, looking out at the garden together. "The climbing rose looks happy," Leo murmured, taking a sip of his coffee. "She likes the morning sun." It was no longer Max's garden being commented on by a hired professional. It was theirs, a shared concern, a mutual point of reference. In that moment, watching the dawn break with Leo by his side, Max felt a kind of peace that had nothing to do with victory or a clean sheet. It was the quiet, unassuming peace of being known.

Their bubble of domestic bliss was intoxicating. The rigid, unforgiving structure of Max’s life began to soften and bend. Tuesdays and Fridays lost their ceremonial significance, bleeding into the rest of the week. Leo would sometimes stay over on a Wednesday, or come for dinner on a Sunday after Max’s match. He kept a toothbrush in the minimalist bathroom, a splash of colour and ordinariness against the stark white marble. He brought over a few of his books, placing them on Max’s meticulously empty bedside table, and the sight of their worn, colourful spines was more beautiful to Max than any work of art he owned. Max, in turn, found himself hurrying home from training, the lure of the locker room banter and optional gym sessions losing all appeal. He wanted to come home to the smell of Leo cooking, or the sight of him curled in the armchair, lost in a book, his feet tucked up under him. The fortress was becoming a home, one day, one shared meal, one quiet evening at a time.

The inevitable intrusion of the outside world came not with a bang, but with the quiet, insidious click of a long-lens camera. It happened on a Saturday afternoon. They had spent the morning in the garden, a lazy, sun-drenched day of weeding and talking, their hands covered in dirt. They needed more potting soil for Leo’s ever-expanding collection of ‘volunteer’ seedlings he was rescuing, so on a whim, they drove to a large garden centre on the outskirts of the city. Max wore a baseball cap and sunglasses, his usual flimsy armour of anonymity. They wandered the aisles, arguing playfully over the merits of peat-free compost versus loam-based mixes. Max, for the first time in his adult life, felt utterly, blissfully normal. He was just a man with his partner, doing errands on a weekend. He was so absorbed in the simple joy of it, in the way Leo’s eyes lit up when talking about soil aeration, that he failed to notice the man in the corner of the parking lot, the one pretending to look at his phone, the one with the camera bag slung over his shoulder.

The fallout came two days later. Max was stretching after training when Fischer cornered him by the lockers, his face a pale, sweating mask of panic. He didn't speak; he just thrust his phone into Max’s hand. It was a page from a notorious online tabloid. The photo was grainy, clearly taken from a distance, but unmistakable. It was him and Leo, standing by a pallet of compost bags. Max had his sunglasses off and was laughing at something Leo had said. The headline, printed in bold, snide letters, read: *GARDEN LEAVE? MAX RICHTER AND HIS MYSTERY LANDSCAPER GET THEIR HANDS DIRTY*. The article beneath was a toxic stew of innuendo and speculation, questioning Max's "focus" before the start of the season and referring to Leo as his "earthy new companion." It was a violation, a smear of ugly graffiti on the wall of their sanctuary. A cold, hard knot of fury formed in Max's stomach.

He handed the phone back to Fischer, his face impassive, a mask he had perfected over years of press conferences. "And?" he asked, his voice dangerously quiet. "What about it?" Fischer stared at him, aghast. "What about it? Max, this is a disaster! 'Mystery companion'? 'Earthy'? They're painting you as... they're making suggestions! This is off-brand! It's messy! We have to release a statement. A denial. We can say he’s a consultant for a new wellness venture, something we can monetize…" Max held up a hand, and the sheer force of his gaze silenced his agent’s frantic spiral. "No," he said, each word a chip of ice. "We will do nothing. We will say nothing. There is nothing to deny." "But Max, your image—" Fischer began, but Max cut him off. "My image is not your concern right now, Fischer. My *life* is." He turned and walked away, leaving his agent standing open-mouthed, a relic from a world that no longer held any power over him.

The drive home was the longest of his life. The fury had been replaced by a deep, gut-wrenching dread. He had been so careless, so lost in his own happiness that he had forgotten the fundamental rule of his existence: he was public property. He had exposed Leo to the ugliest part of his world, the part he had so desperately wanted to keep him from. He found Leo in the garden, of course, patiently staking the delphiniums. He looked up and smiled as Max approached, a smile that faltered when he saw the look on Max's face. Max didn't know how to begin, so he just held out his own phone, the webpage already open. He watched as Leo read it, his expression slowly changing from confusion to a quiet, stony stillness. He scrolled through the article, his face unreadable. When he finished, he didn't look angry. He just looked tired. "Oh," he said softly. "So this is what it's like."

Max’s heart fractured. "Leo, I am so sorry," he choked out. "I was stupid. I should have known. I never should have—" Leo held up a hand, stopping him. He looked from the phone to Max's anguished face. "This isn't your fault, Max," he said, his voice steady, though his eyes were clouded. "You didn't take the picture. You just wanted to buy some soil." He handed the phone back to Max, his movements deliberate. He looked around the garden, at the peaceful, ordered world they had built together. "Is it going to be like this now? Hiding? Looking over our shoulders?" The question was quiet, but it held the weight of their entire future. Max looked at the man before him, the man who had coaxed life from dead earth, the man who had taught him how to breathe again, and he felt a clarity so fierce and absolute it burned away all his fear. He had been protecting his sanctuary, but he had it backwards. The garden wasn't the sanctuary. Leo was. "No," Max said, his voice ringing with a conviction he had never felt before. He stepped forward and took Leo's face in his hands, forcing him to meet his gaze. "No. I am done hiding. I will not let them turn you into a secret. You are the most real thing in my life, and I will not treat you like a dirty one. Let them write what they want. It doesn't matter. All that matters is right here." He was no longer just choosing Leo over his brand. He was choosing life over a career, substance over image. And in the quiet of their garden, with the world's ugly noise raging outside their walls, it felt like the only victory that had ever truly mattered.

Leo listened, his gaze fixed on Max’s face, searching for the slightest crack in the conviction, the faintest flicker of fear. But there was none. What he saw was a man reforged, the brittle alloy of fame and pressure burned away to reveal a core of unshakeable resolve. He saw the man who had knelt in the dirt, clumsy and determined, to learn the difference between a weed and a flower. He saw the man who had chosen a shared, messy meal in a noisy trattoria over the sterile perfection of his own life. The tabloid photos and the ugly words were a violation, a storm that threatened to flatten the fragile life they had planted, but Max was standing firm, a stake driven deep into the ground, refusing to let them break. The fear in Leo’s own heart, the cold dread of being dragged into a world he never wanted, began to recede, replaced by a slow, rising tide of fierce, protective love. He reached up and laid his palm flat against Max’s chest, feeling the steady, powerful rhythm of his heart beneath the thin fabric of his shirt.

“Okay,” Leo said, his voice quiet but unwavering. “Then we don’t hide.” It was not a capitulation; it was an alliance. A choice made with open eyes. The relief that washed over Max’s face was so profound it was almost painful to witness. He closed his eyes for a moment, a silent, shuddering breath escaping him. When he opened them again, the anguish was gone, replaced by a look of such raw gratitude that it made Leo’s own heart ache. They didn't kiss. The moment was too solemn, a silent vow exchanged in the fading light. Instead, Max kept his hands on Leo’s face, his thumbs stroking his cheeks as if to reassure himself that he was real. It was a promise, a pact made not against the world, but for themselves.

They walked back into the house, but the atmosphere had changed. The idyllic, secret bubble had burst, but what remained was not despair. It was a sober strength, the quiet determination of two people who had just weathered the first true blast of a storm and were still standing, side by side. They spent the evening not in a haze of romantic bliss, but in quiet, practical conversation. They sat at the kitchen island, a map of their new reality spread out between them. Leo asked about Fischer, about the sponsors, about the mechanics of the machine that Max was now defying. Max, in turn, asked about Leo’s other clients, his family, the potential for harassment. He laid out his finances, his legal resources, everything he could offer as a shield, not to hide Leo, but to empower him. It was the least romantic and most intimate conversation they had ever had, a weaving together of their lives that was less about passion and more about the fierce, loyal business of partnership.

The next morning, Max walked into the training facility with a sense of calm he hadn't felt in years. The air in the locker room was thick with unspoken words. Conversations dropped to a hush as he entered, and he was acutely aware of the sideways glances, the phones being quickly pocketed. The usual boisterous camaraderie was replaced by a tense, gossipy curiosity. In the past, this would have sent a spike of anxiety through him, a desperate urge to either deflect with a joke or retreat into an icy silence. Today, he felt nothing but a quiet pity for them, trapped in their world of whispers and speculation. He simply nodded a general greeting to the room, stripped off his street clothes, and began his pre-training routine with a deliberate, unhurried focus that broadcast a single, clear message: he had nothing to hide and nothing to be ashamed of.

His resolve was tested when Klaus, the coach, motioned for him to come to his office. Max followed, his back straight, preparing himself for a lecture on media distractions and team morale. Klaus shut the door and gestured for him to sit. The older man leaned back in his chair, his weathered face impassive, and steepled his fingers, studying Max for a long, silent moment. "I saw the papers," Klaus said, his voice a low gravelly rumble. "The internet." Max met his gaze and nodded once. He offered no explanation, no excuse. Klaus grunted, a sound of grudging acknowledgment. "I have one question, Richter. Is your head on the pitch, or is it somewhere else?"

"It's on the pitch, coach," Max said, his voice even and confident. "It’s clearer than it's been in a long time." Klaus stared at him for another ten seconds, his shrewd eyes assessing, weighing. He had seen hundreds of players derailed by money, by fame, by women, by their own egos. He saw something different in Max now. A stillness. A certainty. "Good," Klaus said, finally. "I don't give a damn who you're planting roses with, as long as you're in the box when the ball comes across. Now get out of my office and go score some goals." The dismissal was the most profound expression of support Max could have possibly received. He walked out of the office feeling ten feet taller, the quiet backing of this one pragmatic, honourable man a more powerful shield than any PR statement.

The final battle was with Fischer. His agent ambushed him on his way out of the facility, his face a mess of theatrical despair. "Max! Thank God! I've been calling. We have a five-alarm fire here! The watch company is invoking the morals clause, the car sponsor is threatening to pull the new campaign. We need to get ahead of this, now!"
