He tried to steer Max towards his car, already talking about a carefully staged interview with a sympathetic female journalist. Max stopped walking, planting his feet on the asphalt of the parking lot. He waited for Fischer to finish his breathless, panicked monologue, his own expression one of complete, unnerving calm. When Fischer finally ran out of air, Max looked him squarely in the eye.

"Listen to me very carefully, Fischer," he said, his voice low and devoid of all emotion. "Leo Hansen is my partner. He is not a public relations crisis, and he is not a marketing opportunity. He is a non-negotiable fact of my life." He took a step closer, forcing his agent to meet his unwavering gaze. "So here is the new strategy. Any sponsor who has a problem with who I love can terminate their contract. I'll pay the penalty. Any media outlet that harasses him, his family, or his clients will be sued for every penny they have. You will not issue any statements. You will not deny anything. You will not 'spin' anything. Your only job is to field the offers that come from people who want to work with Max Richter, the footballer, the man. Not the brand. Are we clear?" Fischer stared, his mouth opening and closing silently, the gears of his opportunistic mind grinding to a halt against this immovable object. Max didn't wait for an answer. He turned his back on his sputtering agent and walked to his car, the weight of a decade-long performance finally, completely, lifted from his shoulders. He was free.

### Chapter 7

The days that followed were a strange exercise in living within a bubble of their own creation, while simultaneously being aware of the storm raging just outside its invisible walls. They did not read the articles or watch the gossip shows. They muted Fischer’s name when it flashed on the phone. Instead, they focused on the tangible. They planted a small herb garden in a series of terracotta pots on the patio, a little echo of Leo’s balcony in Altona. They cooked. They took long walks in the early morning along the banks of the Elbe, when the city was still misty and asleep, their world reduced to the crunch of gravel underfoot and the comfortable space between their shoulders. Max learned the particular cadence of Leo’s breathing as he slept. Leo learned that Max, despite his intimidating prowess on the pitch, was laughably inept at folding fitted sheets. It was a period of intense, quiet discovery, a deliberate building of a fortress made not of stone and glass, but of shared moments and small, irrefutable truths. The noise from the outside was just weather, and they had found their shelter.

The first game of the official season arrived like a summons. It was an away match, which in some ways was worse. A home crowd might offer some measure of loyalty, but a rival stadium would be a crucible of hostility. The morning of the match, an unspoken tension settled over the house. Leo was quieter than usual, his movements around the kitchen more deliberate. When Max was dressed in his club suit, ready to leave for the team bus, Leo met him at the door. He didn't wish him luck or tell him to be careful. He simply reached out and straightened Max’s tie, a small, intimate gesture that spoke volumes. He smoothed the lapels of the suit, his hands firm and steady. "Just play your game, Max," he said, his voice low and certain. "That’s all." He looked Max directly in the eye, and in his gaze, Max saw not fear, but an unshakeable faith. It was a better shield than any armour.

The bus ride to the stadium was a study in strained silence. His teammates, unsure of the correct etiquette, defaulted to a polite but distant neutrality. They talked about the weather, about the pitch conditions, about anything other than the one subject that was on everyone’s mind. Max didn't try to fill the silence. He just stared out the window, watching the landscape blur by, his mind calm. He wasn't afraid. The fear of public opinion, which had been a constant, low-grade fever his entire career, was simply gone. What was left was a quiet resolve. As the bus pulled into the stadium's underground entrance, the first shouts became audible. They were muffled by the concrete walls, but the tone was clear. It was a chorus of jeers, interspersed with crude, homophobic slurs. Max felt a flicker of the old, familiar ice in his veins, but then he thought of Leo, straightening his tie, his expression full of trust. The jeers were just noise. He stepped off the bus and walked into the belly of the beast, his head held high.

The venom of the crowd was a physical presence during warm-ups. Every time Max touched the ball, a wave of boos and whistles washed down from the stands. Banners had been confiscated by security, but he could imagine what they said. He went through his drills with a Zen-like focus, blocking out the noise, concentrating only on the feel of the ball at his feet, the stretch of his muscles, the rhythm of his own breathing. He was a craftsman preparing his tools, oblivious to the baying of the mob. When the whistle blew for kickoff, he was no longer thinking about the crowd, or the headlines, or even Leo. He was thinking only of the geometry of the pitch, the movement of his teammates, the ninety minutes of work that lay ahead. And he played with a joy and freedom he hadn't felt since he was a boy kicking a ball against a garage door. He was no longer playing for the approval of fifty thousand screaming throats. He was playing for the sheer, unadulterated love of the game.

Midway through the second half, the score tied, he found his moment. A cross came in from the wing, a high, looping ball that seemed to hang in the air for an eternity. The roar of the crowd was a distant, irrelevant hum. He saw the trajectory, calculated the spin, and moved. His jump was perfectly timed, his body rising to meet the ball in a symphony of practiced motion. The header was clean, powerful, and precise, sending the ball rocketing into the top corner of the net. For a single, stunned second, the entire stadium fell silent. The silence was broken by the ecstatic shouts of his teammates as they swarmed him. In that moment of triumph, his gaze instinctively flickered up to the stands, a reflexive search for a face he knew wouldn't be there. But he wasn't looking for approval. He was sending a message, a quiet signal across the miles: *This is for us*.

The mandatory post-game interview was a gantlet of microphones and cameras on the edge of the pitch. Max, his face flushed with exertion and victory, faced the scrum. The first few questions were standard football fare. Then, a reporter from a notoriously aggressive British tabloid pushed his way to the front. "Max," he began, his voice slick with faux concern, "a fantastic goal to silence the critics tonight. There's been a lot of speculation about distractions in your personal life affecting your game. Do you feel you've answered those questions on the pitch today?" The baited trap was laid. Every camera zoomed in, every microphone strained to catch his reply. Max held the reporter's gaze, a faint, almost pitying smile on his lips. He took a breath. "I have never been more focused," he said, his voice calm and clear, carrying easily over the stadium noise. "Or happier. I think a person plays their best football when they have nothing to hide." He gave a slight nod, a gesture of finality, and turned and walked away towards the tunnel, leaving the entire press corps in a state of stunned, speechless silence.

He drove himself home that night, turning down the team dinner. The city lights smeared across his windscreen, but he was no longer seeing them as watercolour paints in a life he wasn't living. They were just lights, in a city that was now his home. When he unlocked his front door, the house was quiet, but it was a warm, breathing quiet. A single lamp was on in the living room, casting a soft golden glow. Leo was asleep in the big armchair, a book fallen open on his chest, his head tilted at an angle that was probably going to give him a stiff neck. The television was off. He hadn't been watching the game. He had simply been waiting. Max walked over and gently eased the book from his chest, placing a bookmark in the page. He knelt by the chair, and just watched him sleep for a long moment, this man who was his partner, his sanctuary, his quiet harbour. He brushed a stray lock of sandy hair from Leo's forehead, his touch infinitely gentle. Leo stirred, his eyes fluttering open, clouded with sleep. He blinked a few times, focusing on Max’s face. A slow, sleepy smile spread across his lips. "Hey," he murmured. "You're home." Max leaned in and kissed him, a soft, lingering kiss that tasted of victory, and freedom, and the profound, quiet peace of coming home to the only person in the world who mattered.

The first thing Max heard the next morning was the sound of secateurs. It was a crisp, rhythmic *snip-snip-snip* from the garden, a sound so familiar and comforting that for a moment he thought it was Tuesday. He opened his eyes to the soft grey light of his bedroom and the empty space beside him. He sat up, the aches from the previous night's game settling into his bones, and walked to the window. Down below, in the cool morning mist, Leo was deadheading the roses, his movements methodical and calm, as if it were the most ordinary day in the world. Max watched him for a long moment, a profound sense of peace settling over him. The world could rage, but here, in their garden, the rhythm of life continued, steady and unbroken.

He pulled on a sweatshirt and went downstairs, a mug of coffee in hand. Leo looked up as he approached, a small, genuine smile touching his lips. There were no congratulations, no discussion of the goal or the interview. "The aphids are making a move on the new buds," Leo said, his voice matter-of-fact as he pointed with his clippers. "We need to get some ladybirds." The sheer normality of it was the most loving gesture Max could have imagined. It was a statement: what you do on the pitch is your work, but this, here, is our life. Max knelt beside him, the damp earth seeping into the knees of his trousers, and began examining the afflicted buds, his focus narrowing to this small, immediate, solvable problem.

It was almost noon when Max finally brought the outside world into their sanctuary. He sat on the patio steps, Leo beside him, and pulled up a news site on his phone. He didn’t read the sensationalist tabloids, but a major sports publication. The headline was simple: *MAX RICHTER: "I HAVE NEVER BEEN HAPPIER."* Below it, they had embedded the clip of his interview. He angled the phone so they could both see, and pressed play. He watched himself on the small screen, saw the calm defiance in his own eyes, heard the steady conviction in his voice. He had expected to feel a jolt of anxiety, a pang of fear at the finality of it. Instead, he felt a quiet pride. Beside him, Leo watched intently, his expression unreadable. When the clip finished, Leo didn't speak for a long time. He just reached out and took Max's hand, his fingers, cool from the morning air, lacing through Max's. "The man who couldn't make conversation," Leo said softly, a universe of affection and admiration in his voice, "turns out to be a poet after all."

The ensuing phone call from Fischer was a study in whiplash. The agent’s voice, stripped of its despair, was now a high-pitched hum of frantic, giddy energy. "Max, it's unbelievable! My phone is a fireworks display! The league's head office put out a statement about 'supporting all our athletes' and 'fostering an inclusive environment'! The car company isn't pulling out; they're talking about a new campaign focused on 'authentic journeys'! A massive sportswear brand, a competitor of your current shoe sponsor, wants an urgent meeting! They're talking about building a whole campaign around you, Max! Not the brand, you! The man! It's genius! It’s—" Max held the phone away from his ear, a wry, tired smile touching his lips. He looked at Leo, who was listening with an expression of deep amusement. Max had broken the machine, and in its confusion, it was trying to reassemble itself around him in a new shape. "That's great, Fischer," he said, cutting him off. "Handle the meetings. Send me the offers. And double the retainer for my legal team. I have a feeling they'll be busy." He hung up, shaking his head at the beautiful, cynical absurdity of it all. He hadn't done it for a campaign; he had done it for peace. The fact that the world was trying to commodify his peace was an irony he was sure Leo's father would have appreciated.

The true test, he knew, was not in the headlines or the boardrooms. It was here, in the quiet of their home. "They’ll find you," Max said later that evening, his voice serious as they sat in the deepening twilight. "Reporters. Photographers. They'll find your building in Altona. They'll try to talk to your neighbours, your other clients." Leo, who was carefully repotting an orchid, didn't look up from his work. He gently teased a root from a tangled mass, his touch infinitely patient. "I've already called Mrs. Schmidt," he said calmly, referring to his oldest client, a formidable widow in her eighties. "I told her that if anyone claiming to be a 'friend of Leo's' comes asking questions, she has my permission to use her hose on them." He finally looked up, a glint of steel in his blue eyes. "My life is my life, Max. It’s a bit smaller and quieter than yours, but it's just as real. They can take pictures of my door. They can't take anything that matters."

A week later, on the day of the first home game of the season, Max stood before the walk-in closet that had once felt like an armoury for a man going to war. Today, it felt different. He pulled out the dark club suit, the fabric familiar in his hands. There was a knock on the open door, and he turned to see Leo leaning against the frame, holding two mugs of coffee. "Big day," Leo said, his tone light. Max nodded, taking a mug. "I want you to be there," he said, the words he'd been rehearsing in his head all morning. "Not hiding in the stands or watching on TV. I want you in the family box. With my mother, when she comes. With the other partners." It was the final wall to be demolished, the last vestige of separation between his two worlds. He was inviting Leo not just into his home, but into his public life, a place of privilege and intense scrutiny. Leo looked at him, his gaze steady over the rim of his mug. He took a slow sip before answering. "Okay," he said simply. "But on one condition." Max raised an eyebrow. "You have to properly introduce me to Klaus after the match," Leo said, a small smile playing on his lips. "I want to shake the hand of the man who cares more about goals than gossip."

And so, two hours later, when Max Richter walked out of the tunnel into the roaring, adoring cauldron of his home stadium, he knew that for the first time, he was not alone. He knew that up in the glass-fronted box, sitting amongst the wives and girlfriends and parents, was a gardener with dirt under his fingernails and unwavering faith in his eyes. The roar of the crowd washed over him, fifty-seven thousand throats screaming his name. But this time, it wasn't a drug or a poison. It was just the beautiful, chaotic, wonderful sound of his team’s supporters. The only voice that truly mattered was the quiet one he would come home to. He took his position on the pitch, the green expanse stretching out before him like a promise. The game was about to begin. The garden was in order. He was ready to play.

### Chapter 8

From his seat behind the soundproof glass of the family box, Leo felt like an anthropologist observing a strange and baffling tribe. The air was thick with expensive perfume and a high-strung, nervous energy that seemed completely at odds with the plush, silent luxury of the surroundings. The other partners, a flock of brightly-coloured birds in designer labels, fluttered with every near-miss on the pitch below, their gasps and cries muted by the thick glass. They offered him polite, curious smiles, their eyes sliding over his simple dark sweater and worn jeans with a practiced, neutral appraisal. He felt not so much out of place as simply of a different element, a creature of soil and sun adrift in a hermetically sealed world of champagne and anxiety. He found a strange comfort in the disconnect. Below him, the pitch was a perfect, almost unnaturally green rectangle, a world away from the chaotic, beautiful mess of a real garden. And on it, Max moved with a familiar, lethal grace, a figure made small by distance but utterly commanding in his focus.

He fell into the rhythm of the game, letting the ebb and flow of the match wash over him. He began to see it less as a sport and more as a complex, shifting ecosystem, a constant battle for space and opportunity. He saw the patterns Max exploited, the work he did off the ball that went unnoticed by the gasping crowd but was integral to the team's structure. A young woman next to him, her hands twisting an expensive silk scarf into a knot, introduced herself as Lena, the girlfriend of the team's rookie midfielder. Her nerves were palpable, her anxiety a constant hum. She seemed surprised by Leo's calm, by his quiet observation. They made small talk about the oppressive heat of the box and the shocking price of the bottled water, and Leo found that in this alien environment, his own quiet nature acted as a strange kind of anchor, both for himself and for the nervous young woman beside him. He was just Leo, a man watching a game, and that, it turned out, was enough.

The moment came just before halftime. Max received the ball at the edge of the penalty area, a position from which he had created a thousand chances. Time seemed to slow. He feinted left, a subtle drop of the shoulder that sent the defender sliding past him, and in the sliver of space he had created, he unleashed a low, powerful shot that seemed to skim the surface of the perfect grass, tucking itself just inside the far post. The stadium erupted, the muffled roar pressing in on the glass of the box like a physical force. As his teammates buried him in a pile of ecstatic limbs, Max fought his way free, his gaze lifting immediately to the box. He couldn't possibly make out individual faces from that distance, but his eyes found the exact spot where Leo was sitting. He raised a hand, not a triumphant fist for the cameras, but a simple, open-palmed wave, a private signal across a sea of noise. It was a gesture that said, *I see you. This is for us.* Leo felt a warmth spread through his chest, a quiet joy that had nothing to do with the scoreboard.

After the final whistle confirmed a decisive home victory, the stadium slowly began to empty, its energy dissipating into the evening sky. Max bypassed the first wave of clamouring reporters, his focus singular. He met Leo at the private entrance to the hospitality suites, the transition from the roaring public space to the quiet, functional corridor abrupt and disorienting. Leo’s face was calm, but his eyes were shining with a pride that needed no words. "You were good," he said, the simple statement landing with more weight than any sportscaster’s hyperbole. Max’s answering smile was radiant. He took Leo’s hand, a natural, possessive gesture that did not go unnoticed by the handful of club staff and security personnel lingering in the hallway. He didn’t care. He led Leo down a series of corridors, deeper into the stadium's inner sanctum, towards the coach's office.

Klaus's door was ajar, and Max knocked once before entering, Leo a half-step behind him. The coach was studying a tablet, his face illuminated by the screen's glow. He looked up, his gaze moving from Max to Leo, his expression unreadable. He lumbered to his feet, a formidable, stocky figure who seemed to take up all the oxygen in the small office. "Coach, this is Leo Hansen," Max said, his voice steady. Klaus extended a large, calloused hand. "Hansen," he grunted, a sound of gruff acknowledgment. "The gardener." Leo shook his hand, his own grip firm and sure. "I know a stubborn root when I see one," Leo replied, a faint, wry smile touching his lips. "They tend to get the best results if you give them the right conditions." A look of silent, masculine understanding passed between the two men. It was an exchange that lasted no more than thirty seconds, but in the quiet space of the coach’s office, a treaty of mutual respect was signed.

As they stepped back into the corridor, they nearly collided with Matthias, the team captain, a jovial bear of a man, his face still flushed from the game. He clapped Max on the back, nearly knocking the breath from him. "Hell of a game, Richter! That turn was pure filth." His gaze shifted to Leo, his smile broad and unwavering. "Leo, right? Matthias. Welcome to the circus." He offered a hand, which Leo shook. "Max has been going on about his 'horticultural therapy'," Matthias boomed, his voice echoing in the concrete hallway. "Says you've got him pulling weeds like a penitent monk. Whatever you're doing, keep it up. We haven't seen him play this free in years." The blunt, good-natured acceptance was like a fresh breeze, clearing away the last lingering wisps of locker-room awkwardness. The 'scandal' was over. Leo was simply a part of the new reality, a fixture in the life of their star striker.

The drive home was quiet, the city lights painting fleeting patterns across the windscreen. The adrenaline of the game and the public debut receded, leaving behind a deep, settled contentment. When they walked through the front door, the house was silent, but it was a warm, welcoming silence, the kind that waits for you at the end of a long day. Leo put the kettle on while Max changed out of his suit, letting it fall in a heap on the bedroom floor like a shed skin. He found Leo on the patio, looking up at the night sky, a mug of tea warming his hands. "It was loud," Leo said, his voice thoughtful. "All that energy, all focused on one small space. It's… a lot." Max came to stand beside him, wrapping an arm around his shoulders and pulling him close, their bodies fitting together in a now-familiar alignment. "The quiet is better," Max said, his voice a low murmur against Leo's hair. The roar was for the world. The silence, this peaceful, star-dusted quiet, was just for them. The garden around them was dark and sleeping, holding its breath for the morning. They were home.

The weeks that followed settled into a new kind of normal, a rhythm dictated less by the football league's schedule and more by the turning of the seasons. Summer's lush, almost frantic growth gave way to the deeper, burnished tones of early autumn. The air grew crisp, and the light slanted lower across the garden, turning the silver birch into a column of pale gold. The boisterous lavender was pruned back, its energy directed inward for the coming winter. The last of the roses bloomed, their crimson petals seeming even deeper and more velvety against the cooling air. Their life together settled, too, its roots digging deeper, drawing strength from the quiet, unremarkable days.

Their sanctuary, once a secret held between them, slowly and carefully expanded its borders. Lena, the midfielder’s girlfriend, started seeking Leo out in the family box before games, her own nervous energy soothed by his calm presence. They would talk about her struggles with a wilting ficus in her city-centre flat, and Leo would offer quiet, practical advice. Matthias, the team captain, and his wife invited them over for a barbecue, a boisterous, chaotic affair with toddlers and dogs underfoot. Max, for the first time, found himself in a teammate's home not as a fellow superstar, but as half of a couple, helping to clear plates and talking about something other than football. He watched Leo, completely at ease, discussing drainage solutions for a waterlogged lawn with Matthias's wife, and felt a wave of love so profound it almost buckled his knees. He was not just bringing Leo into his world; he was building a new world with him, a world with barbecues and conversations about sick houseplants.

The real test, however, came not from Max’s world, but from Leo’s. It was a Tuesday, and they were working together in the garden, harvesting the last of the sun-warmed tomatoes from a small plant Leo had brought over from his balcony. “My friend, Anja, is having a birthday thing on Saturday,” Leo said, his voice casual as he pinched a tomato from its vine. “At her flat in Sternschanze. It'll be just a bunch of us. Music, cheap wine, too many people crammed into a small space. You should come.” He held out a perfect, ruby-red tomato, an echo of the first one he had ever offered Max. But this offering was different. It wasn’t an invitation into a secret garden; it was an invitation into the heart of his life, into the community of people who had known him long before Max Richter ever knew his name.

Max felt a jolt of anxiety that was shockingly familiar, the same cold dread he used to feel before a high-stakes match. He could face down a stadium of hostile fans, a firing squad of journalists, a boardroom of angry sponsors. But the thought of a dozen of Leo’s friends, a group of artists and booksellers and teachers, all crammed into a small flat, scrutinizing him not as a football god but as the man who was dating their Leo—that was terrifying. What would he talk about? His multi-million-euro contract? His tedious media obligations? His life was a foreign country, and he didn't speak the language. “Of course,” he heard himself say, the words a testament to his love for the man beside him. “I’d love to.”

On Saturday evening, standing in front of his closet, he felt a paralysis even more acute than the first time he had driven to Altona. Every piece of clothing he owned felt like a costume. The designer clothes were too loud, the simple jeans and t-shirts a pathetic attempt at camouflage. He was a wolf trying to dress up as a house cat. Leo, watching him from the doorway with an amused, affectionate smile, finally took pity on him. He walked over, pulled out a simple, well-worn dark green button-down shirt of his own from a small pile he now kept in Max’s closet, and handed it to him. “Wear this,” he said softly. “It already smells like me. It’ll be like a security blanket.” The gesture was so tender, so understanding, that Max felt the knot in his stomach loosen. He was not going into this alone. He was going as Leo’s partner.

Anja’s apartment was on the third floor of a graffiti-adorned building, and the sounds of music and laughter spilled out into the stairwell. The moment they stepped inside, they were enveloped in a wave of warmth, noise, and the smell of mulled wine. The flat was a glorious, cluttered haven of books, art, and mismatched furniture. And it was packed. Leo was immediately swept up in a hug by a woman with vibrant pink hair and a smile that lit up the room—Anja, the birthday girl. “Leo! You made it! And you brought the celebrity!” she exclaimed, her voice teasing but her eyes kind as she looked at Max. “Anja,” Leo said, a warning tone in his voice. “Be nice.” She just laughed and threw an arm around Leo’s shoulders. “I’m always nice! It’s an honour, Max. Anyone who can get this one to miss a Friday night repotting session is a miracle worker in my book.” She handed them both glasses of wine and was immediately pulled away into another conversation. The introduction was over in ten seconds, painless and utterly normal.

Max stayed close to Leo’s side at first, a quiet satellite in his orbit, letting Leo’s easy conversations wash over him. He was introduced as “my partner, Max,” the words simple, solid, and offered without fanfare. No one asked him about football. A man with paint-stained fingers asked him about the book he was currently reading. A woman who taught primary school asked for his opinion on the fiercely debated playlist. He was treated not with awe or suspicion, but with a friendly, slightly reserved curiosity, the kind reserved for the new boyfriend of a beloved friend. He was being judged on a curve, his primary qualification being that Leo had chosen him. It was a humbling and profoundly moving experience. After a while, Leo was pulled into a deep discussion about a friend’s ailing olive tree, and Max found himself on his own, leaning against a bookshelf, just watching. He saw Leo in his natural element, laughing, gesturing, his face animated and open. He saw the easy intimacy, the shared histories, the deep, comfortable affection that bound this group of people together. This was the soil from which Leo had grown, the community that had shaped him. And they had, quietly and without fuss, made a small space for him. He was not an intruder; he was just a new branch, being carefully grafted on.

Later in the evening, after the cake had been cut and the mulled wine had been replaced by beer and whatever spirits people had brought, Max found himself momentarily alone again. He was in a slightly quieter corner, examining a strange, beautiful print on the wall—a detailed botanical illustration of a plant that looked both beautiful and vaguely menacing. Anja appeared at his side, a fresh glass of wine in her hand. For a moment, they just looked at the print together. "Datura," she said, her voice softer now, stripped of its party hostess energy. "Beautiful, intoxicating, and poisonous as hell. A fitting plant for a cynic like me." She took a sip of her wine and then turned her full attention on him. Her gaze was direct and disconcertingly intelligent. "Leo is the least cynical person I know," she continued, her tone shifting from casual to pointed. "He thinks anything can be saved. He'll spend a month trying to rescue a half-dead seedling that anyone else would have thrown on the compost heap. Most of the time, he’s right."

Max understood immediately that they were no longer talking about plants. This was the real conversation, the true test of the evening. He met her gaze, not with a defensive posture, but with a quiet acknowledgment. "I know," he said, his voice low. "I was that seedling." The confession was stark and unadorned, and it surprised even himself. He hadn't planned to say it, but it was the simplest, most honest truth he possessed. Anja’s expression softened, the sharpness in her eyes giving way to a thoughtful curiosity. "He deserves a place that gets the morning sun, you know?" she said, her voice now gentle. "Not a glass house he's just tending. He deserves a garden of his own." Max nodded, the metaphor landing with perfect, painful clarity. "I know," he said again, and this time his voice was thick with emotion. "I'm not trying to be his garden. I'm just hoping he'll let me build a life with him on his balcony." For a long moment, Anja just studied his face. Then, a slow, genuine smile bloomed, a mirror of the one she’d given Leo hours earlier. She raised her glass in a silent toast, a gesture of acceptance more profound than any loud declaration. "Good," she said simply. "That's all we wanted to know."

The walk back to where Max had parked the car was through silent, sleeping streets, the distant sounds of the city a low hum beneath their feet. The air was cool and smelled of rain and fallen leaves. Leo was quiet, his shoulder brushing against Max’s as they walked. The comfortable silence was a stark contrast to the lively chaos of the party. Finally, Leo spoke, his voice thoughtful. "Were you okay back there? I saw Anja corner you. She can be… intense. She thinks of herself as my fiercely protective older sister." Max smiled into the darkness. "It was fine. We talked about plants." He felt Leo look at him, could feel his partner's skepticism even without seeing it. "And seedlings," Max amended. "She's a good friend, Leo. You're lucky." They walked a few more steps in silence before Leo spoke again, his own voice laced with a vulnerability Max had rarely heard. "I was nervous," he admitted. "For you. That world... it's not yours. I was worried you'd feel like an exhibit."

Max stopped walking, turning to face Leo under the amber glow of a lone streetlight. He reached out and cupped Leo’s cheek, his thumb stroking the curve of his jaw. "It's your world, Leo. That makes it part of mine now. It felt... real. More real than any gala or awards dinner I've ever been to." He looked into Leo's eyes, trying to convey the depth of what he was feeling. "Watching you with them, seeing the life you've built, the people who love you for exactly who you are... it wasn't intimidating. It just made me love you more." The admission hung in the quiet street, simple and absolute. Leo’s face softened, and he leaned into Max's touch, his eyes closing for a moment. "Good," he murmured, his voice thick. "Because I'm quite fond of you too, even if you still don't know the difference between a perennial and an annual." Max laughed, a low, happy sound, and leaned in to kiss him, a quiet, reassuring kiss under a solitary city streetlight that felt more significant than any stadium-sized victory.

When they got back to the house in Othmarschen, the transition from the lived-in, bohemian streets of Sternschanze to the silent, minimalist grandeur of Max's neighbourhood was more jarring than ever. The house stood like a pale ghost in the moonlight, a monument to a life of curated emptiness. But as Max unlocked the door and they stepped inside, the feeling was different. The silence that greeted them was not sterile; it was peaceful. It was the quiet of a shared home at the end of a long night. While Max went to get them both glasses of water, Leo drifted into the living room. He noticed that a large coffee table book on architecture, which had sat in the exact same spot on the low marble table for a year, had been moved. In its place was one of the slim volumes of poetry he had brought from his flat, left open on the sofa. Beside it, on the pristine white wool of the rug, was a small, overturned terracotta pot and a faint dusting of dry soil, remnants of a repotting project from the afternoon that they had left in their hurry to get to the party. Leo smiled. The house was no longer a gallery. It was acquiring the beautiful, untidy layers of a life being lived. Max returned with the water and saw him looking at the mess on the floor. "Sorry about that," Max said, a hint of the old, reflexive embarrassment in his voice. "I should clean that up." Leo shook his head, walking over to him and taking a glass. He looked around the room, at the book, at the stray dirt, at Max standing there in his borrowed shirt. "Don't," he said softly, his eyes shining. "It's perfect. It's finally starting to look like someone actually lives here."

### Chapter 9

The house in Othmarschen began to breathe. The change was gradual, an slow, organic colonization of the minimalist space. It started with a stack of Leo’s worn gardening books appearing on a pristine white shelf in the living room, their cracked spines and dog-eared pages a warm, rebellious note against the curated emptiness. Then, one weekend, his battered record player was installed on a credenza, and the vast, echoing silence was filled with the melancholic, intricate melodies of The National, or the raw, honest voice of a folk singer Max had never heard of. Max found he preferred this gentle clutter to the sterile quiet he had once mistaken for peace. He started leaving small instructions for the cleaning staff, notes that felt like minor acts of treason against his former self: *Please don’t worry about the smudges on the glass doors to the patio. Please leave the books on the coffee table as they are.* A smudge, a bit of stray soil on the floor, a half-empty mug left by the armchair—these were no longer offenses against order. They were the brushstrokes of a life being painted, the beautiful, untidy evidence that he was no longer alone.

As autumn deepened, the garden began its slow, graceful retreat. Leo spent his days preparing the earth for its winter sleep, mulching the beds with a thick blanket of compost, wrapping the most delicate roses in burlap like sleeping children. It was a time of patience, of trust in the unseen life that lay dormant beneath the cooling soil. Their relationship mirrored this seasonal shift. The frantic, explosive discovery of the early days settled into a deeper, quieter rhythm. They spent more evenings indoors, curled on the sofa in a tangle of limbs and blankets, the rain-streaked panoramic window reflecting the warm light of the lamp beside them. Their conversations, once focused on the immediate, thrilling present, began to drift towards the future, a vast, uncharted territory they were only just beginning to map.

The question arose on a cold, rainy Sunday in late November, the kind of day designed for introspection. The season was nearing its end, with only a few games left before the long winter break. They were wrapped in a shared duvet on the sofa, listening to the rain drum against the roof. “What happens,” Max began, his voice a low murmur against Leo’s hair, “when the season ends?” He let the question hang in the comfortable quiet. “You’re still paying rent on your flat in Altona. You’re there maybe one night a week. It doesn’t make sense.” The question was practical, logistical, but they both knew it was loaded with the weight of a much larger conversation about permanence, about what came next.

Max felt Leo tense slightly in his arms, a subtle bracing. He knew he had to tread carefully. He disentangled himself enough to look Leo in the face, his expression earnest. “I don’t want you to just move in,” he said, anticipating the fear he knew Leo must feel, the fear of being subsumed. “This house… I bought it, but I never made it a home. It was built for the brand, for Max Richter the footballer, not for us. I don’t want you to feel like you’re just a guest in my space, like you’re living on my territory. I don’t want to be the one who takes your balcony away from you.” The admission was a testament to how far he had come, his ability to see his own life, his own home, through Leo’s eyes, and to recognise its potential as a beautiful, gilded cage.

Leo was quiet for a long time, his gaze distant as he watched the rain distort the garden into a watercolour of greens and greys. “I love being here,” he said finally, his voice soft but clear. “Because you’re here. But the flat in Altona… it’s mine. I know where every squeaky floorboard is. I can drill a hole in the wall to hang a picture without asking an architect if it compromises the aesthetic integrity.” A small, wry smile touched his lips. “Your house is beautiful, Max. It’s a work of art. But it’s not a place that feels like it’s meant to be touched. I miss my mess. I miss my chaos. I miss having a space that I’ve built myself, even if it is just a tiny balcony crammed with too many pots.” Anja’s words from the party echoed in Max’s mind: *He deserves a garden of his own.*

A sudden, brilliant idea sparked in Max’s mind, an idea so perfect, so right, that it felt like an epiphany. He sat up, his energy shifting from contemplative to excited. He scrambled for a notepad and a pen from a nearby drawer. “What if we built you a garden you could have all year round?” he said, his voice alive with new purpose. “Right here.” He began to sketch, his lines quick and bold, the years of disciplined focus now channelled into this new creation. “Not just a shed. A proper greenhouse. A conservatory. Glass and steel, maybe some reclaimed brick to warm it up. We could build it off the side of the living room. It would be full of your messy pots and your stubborn tomato plants and a potting bench just for you. It would be your studio, your space, connected to mine. Your balcony,” he said, looking up at Leo, his eyes shining with a desperate, hopeful light, “but with a better budget.”

Leo stared at the sketch taking shape, at the passionate energy radiating from Max. He was momentarily taken aback by the sheer scale of the solution, the quintessential Max-ness of solving the emotional problem of a tiny balcony with a grand architectural gesture. But then he looked past the drawing and into Max’s face, and he saw what was really being offered. It wasn’t a building; it was a bridge. It was Max, the man who had lived in a pristine gallery, offering to add a messy, chaotic, life-filled new wing, just for him. It was a tangible, permanent gesture that said *this is our home, not just mine*. A slow smile spread across Leo’s face, a smile of such deep, unadulterated love that it made Max’s breath catch in his throat. “Okay,” Leo said, his voice thick with emotion as he reached out to trace the lines of Max’s drawing with his finger. “Okay, Max. Let’s build a greenhouse.”

The final game of the season felt less like an ending and more like the clearing of a stage for the next act. Max played with a light and joyous heart, his movements fluid, his mind unburdened. The final whistle blew on a victory, and as he walked off the pitch, saluting the cheering home crowd, he felt no sense of anticlimax, only a quiet, eager anticipation. He drove home not to an ending, but to a beginning. He found Leo in the kitchen, not cooking, but sitting at the vast marble island which he had covered with seed catalogues, architectural magazines, and sheets of tracing paper. Leo was bent over one of Max’s rough sketches, his pencil moving surely, adapting the clean, minimalist lines to the practical needs of light, water, and life. The roar of the stadium was a world away. The only sound in the quiet of their home was the soft scratch of a pencil on paper, the sound of their future being designed.

The winter break began not with the sterile hiss of a plane door sealing him in for a flight to some sun-drenched, soulless resort, but with the soft scratch of a pencil on tracing paper. Max’s usual holiday—a solitary escape to a place where the service was invisible and the luxury was absolute—was replaced by an intense, collaborative domesticity. The vast marble island in the kitchen, once a gleaming, unused expanse, became their command centre. It was covered in a beautiful chaos of Leo’s seed catalogues, Max’s architectural magazines, and endless sketches. Max would draw bold, clean lines, envisioning a structure that was a seamless extension of his minimalist house. Leo would then overlay these drawings with his own, softer lines, annotating them with notes on sun trajectory, ventilation shafts, and the precise height required for a climbing passionfruit vine. It was a negotiation not of wills, but of worlds—a dialogue between form and function, aesthetics and life.

They hired a young, ambitious architect named Sabine, a woman whose portfolio was full of the kind of sharp, glass-and-steel structures Max admired. In their first meeting, she directed her presentation primarily at Max, talking about sightlines, structural integrity, and creating a “dialogue with the existing architecture.” Max listened, nodding along, but found his attention drifting to Leo, who was quietly studying the blueprints, his brow furrowed in concentration. After Sabine’s polished presentation, Leo finally spoke. “Where are the frost-free taps going?” he asked, his voice calm and practical. “And what’s the plan for shading in July? The south-facing glass will cook a tomato plant in two hours. We need external, automated blinds, and at least two roof vents that run on a thermostat for cross-breeze.” Sabine blinked, her well-rehearsed speech momentarily forgotten. The conversation shifted. Max leaned back, a proud, fond smile on his face, and listened as Leo and the architect began a new, more vital dialogue, one about the pragmatics of keeping things alive.

The groundbreaking began in the cold, clear air of early January. The arrival of a small excavator was a brutal, noisy intrusion into the serene, manicured landscape of Othmarschen. It tore a muddy brown scar into the perfect lawn where the foundations would be laid, the sound of its engine a jarring affront to the neighbourhood’s hushed quiet. Max’s neighbours watched from behind their pristine windows, their expressions a mixture of curiosity and disapproval. Max, however, felt a thrill of joy at the disruption. He would come home from his individual training sessions, his body aching from a run, and spend the rest of the afternoon on the construction site, a hard hat perched somewhat ridiculously on his head. He watched the concrete being poured, the first steel beams being bolted into place, fascinated by the process. It was another new language to learn, a craft of precision and heavy labour, and he found it just as grounding as the weeding and pruning had been. This messy, loud, transformative chaos was the sound of his future being built.

In this new environment of hard hats and builders’ jargon, Leo came into his own in a way Max had never seen before. He was no longer just the quiet gardener or the loving partner; he was the expert, the project’s essential core. He moved around the site with a quiet authority, having long conversations with the foreman about drainage gradients and with the electricians about the specific Kelvin temperature required for grow lights. He spoke their language—a language of practicality, of materials, of getting the job done right. The burly, cynical construction crew, who had initially eyed him as the footballer’s “friend,” quickly came to respect him, calling him over to consult on details, valuing his quiet competence over the architect’s grand vision. Max would often stand back and just watch, his heart swelling with a fierce pride. He saw Leo, not as the gentle man who needed shielding, but as a deeply capable, grounded force, commanding respect through his knowledge and passion.

One late afternoon, as a weak winter sun was beginning to dip below the horizon, they stood together inside the half-finished structure. The steel frame was complete, a stark, black skeleton against the bruised purple of the twilight sky. The glass was not yet installed, and the cold wind whistled through the empty panes, carrying the scent of wet earth and steel. From inside, they could see the main house, its lights beginning to glow, looking distant and a little lonely through the skeletal frame of the greenhouse. It was a space between worlds, a bridge not yet complete. Leo reached out and laid his palm flat against a cold steel beam, as if feeling for a pulse. Max came to stand behind him, wrapping his arms around his waist and resting his chin on his shoulder. They stood in silence for a long time, watching their breath fog in the cold air. In that moment, Max realized that this structure, this frame of a room for growing things, meant more to him than any stadium he had ever played in. It was not a monument to his success, but the foundation of his life.

The final, crucial piece of the design came from Leo. He wanted a door. Not a sleek, sliding glass panel that matched the rest of the house, but a real door, reclaimed and solid. “It needs a proper threshold,” he explained, his voice full of a quiet conviction. “Something with a story. A place where the garden ends and the house begins.” Max, who a year ago would have recoiled at the thought of introducing a rustic, imperfect element into his minimalist sanctuary, now saw the genius in it. Their search ended in a sprawling, dusty salvage yard on the industrial outskirts of the city. Tucked away in a corner, they found it: a heavy, weathered oak door, stripped of its paint, with a beautiful, simple iron latch that felt cool and solid in their hands. It had come from a 19th-century farmhouse that had been demolished decades ago. It was scarred with the marks of time, a testament to the lives it had silently witnessed. As they loaded it into the back of a truck, Max looked from the ancient, story-filled wood to Leo’s face, illuminated by a shaft of dusty sunlight. The house was his fortress. The garden was Leo’s sanctuary. This door, he thought, was the perfect symbol of the life they were building: solid, weathered, and strong enough to connect two worlds.

### Chapter 10

The installation of the old oak door was a quiet ceremony. The builders, who had spent weeks working with steel and glass and perfectly poured concrete, treated the ancient wood with a kind of reverence. They heaved it into place, its weathered, scarred surface a stark, beautiful contrast to the sharp, modern lines of the greenhouse frame. Max and Leo stood back, watching as the heavy iron hinges were bolted on, their silence a shared and sacred thing. When it was finally hung, one of the builders wiped his dusty hands on his trousers and pushed it gently. It swung inward on a silent, well-oiled arc, opening a new pathway between the cool, minimalist living room and the raw, earthy potential of the new space. Leo stepped forward and pulled it closed. It shut not with a whisper or a click, but with a deep, resonant *thud*, the sound of solid oak meeting a solid frame, the iron latch settling into place with a satisfying finality. The sound echoed in the quiet house, a declaration of permanence, a closing of one chapter and the solid, certain beginning of another. It was the sound of two worlds becoming one.

The last of the glass was fitted, the automated blinds were wired, and the long slate-topped potting bench was installed beneath a row of windows. The space was finished. It was a beautiful, light-filled emptiness, waiting for its soul. The day they brought the plants from Altona felt like a joyful, slightly chaotic migration. They borrowed a friend’s van and spent the morning carefully packing up the jungle on Leo’s balcony. Anja came to help, bossing Max around with affectionate authority, directing him on how to best cradle a pot of sprawling mint without crushing it. Max, the elite athlete whose body was a finely-tuned instrument of force, discovered a new kind of precision in carrying a fragile, top-heavy pot of herbs down four flights of stairs without snapping a single stem. The neighbours watched from their windows, smiling at the strange procession—the famous footballer, looking endearingly out of his element, carefully loading a van with what looked like the entire contents of a botanical garden. Leo, overseeing it all, had a look of such profound happiness on his face that it made Max’s heart ache.

Back in Othmarschen, they began to populate the new world they had built. One by one, they carried the pots through the old oak door and into the greenhouse. The first to be placed was the magnificent, monstrous tomato plant, given the sunniest corner where its vines could be trained up the steel beams. Then came the pots of rosemary and basil, the boisterous mint, the shy lavender. The space was instantly transformed. The scent of damp earth, crushed herbs, and green, living things filled the air, banishing the sterile smell of new construction. The greenhouse, once just an architectural drawing, came alive, its glass walls holding not just light, but a messy, beautiful, chaotic ecosystem of life. Leo moved through the space with the grace of a conductor settling his orchestra, finding the perfect spot for each plant, considering its need for light and air. Max helped, carrying and fetching, a willing and happy labourer in the creation of their shared sanctuary.

When the last pot was in place, they stood in the middle of the room, surrounded by green. Sunlight, filtered through the new glass, dappled the slate floor. The quiet hum of the automated ventilation system was the only sound. Leo walked over to the new sink, turned on the tap, and filled a simple watering can, the sound of the water a clear, bright music in the new space. He began to water the plants, his movements slow and deliberate, a quiet ritual of settling in. Max didn't help. He just watched, leaning against the frame of the old oak door, his arms crossed over his chest. He was watching a man in his element, a man utterly at peace. He was watching his partner, in a space they had dreamed up together, a space that was a physical manifestation of their love. The sight was so overwhelmingly beautiful, so profoundly right, that it brought a lump to his throat. He had spent his life chasing the roar, the fleeting, explosive high of a goal. He knew now that true joy wasn't a roar. It was this: the quiet sound of water splashing on thirsty leaves, in a room full of life, with the person you love.

That evening, they sat inside the greenhouse as dusk fell, the main house a warm glow behind them. The air was cool but humid, rich with the smell of a hundred living things. Max had carried two chairs in, and they sat with mugs of tea, watching the last of the light fade from the sky. The phantom echo of the stadium, the tinnitus of the soul that had haunted Max for years, was gone. It had not just been silenced; it had been replaced, overwritten by new, better sounds: the solid thud of the old oak door, the quiet snip of secateurs, the splash of water on soil. He reached out and took Leo’s hand, his fingers lacing through his partner’s, the calloused palm a familiar, grounding comfort. He didn’t need to say anything. Everything that needed to be said was here, in this room they had built, in the comfortable silence, in the steady, reassuring pressure of a hand held in his.

A few weeks later, the day before pre-season training was set to begin, Max stood at that same oak door. He was dressed in his training kit, the familiar fabric a second skin. Leo was standing at his potting bench, his back to Max, carefully coaxing a new shoot from an orchid. The quiet, domestic scene was now the bedrock of his life. “I’m heading out,” Max said. Leo turned, a smear of dirt on his cheek and a smile in his eyes. He walked over, wiped his hands on his jeans, and pulled Max in for a kiss, a slow, easy kiss that tasted of coffee and contentment. “Go score some goals,” Leo said softly against his lips, the words no longer a demand from the world, but a simple, loving encouragement. Max smiled, kissed him one last time, and turned to go. As he walked across the immaculate lawn towards his car, he heard a soft, mechanical whir from behind him. The automated vents on the roof of the greenhouse had opened, a quiet sigh as the structure began to breathe in the cool morning air. It was the sound of his home, alive and tended and real. He got into the car, the engine a low, powerful purr, and as he pulled out of the driveway and into the quiet streets of Othmarschen, he felt not the familiar, anxious pull of the stadium, but the calm, certain knowledge of the place he would be coming home to. The roar was a physical thing, a beast that once lived in his bones. But now, it was just a sound. And he knew, with an unshakeable certainty, that the quiet was so much better.

A year later, the greenhouse was no longer a new addition; it was the heart of the house, a lush, humid jungle teeming with life. It had become a vibrant, breathing organ attached to the cool stone body of the main building, and its influence had seeped into every room. There were now trailing plants on top of the kitchen cabinets and a ridiculously oversized fern in the hallway that guests had to duck under. The house had surrendered to the beautiful, persistent chaos of living things. Max sat in a worn wooden armchair tucked into a corner of the greenhouse, a book open but unread in his lap. Outside the glass, a gentle rain was falling, blurring the edges of the autumn garden. Inside, it was warm and smelled of damp earth, night-blooming jasmine, and the sharp tang of citrus from a small lemon tree Leo was fussing over. He watched as Leo, his brow furrowed in concentration, carefully wiped down the lemon tree’s leaves with a soft cloth, murmuring to it as if it were a stubborn but beloved child. The scene was so familiar, so deeply ingrained in the fabric of his new life, that he could scarcely remember the echoing silence that had come before it.

“She’s being dramatic again,” Leo said without turning around, somehow sensing he was being watched. “Thinks a single spider mite is cause for a full-scale emotional collapse.” He finally turned, a fond, exasperated smile on his face. “There’s a reason people say ‘as stubborn as a mule’ and not ‘as stubborn as a citrus tree,’ but they’d be wrong.” He walked over to where Max was sitting, wiping his hands on his jeans, leaving a faint streak of soil. He leaned down and kissed Max, a slow, easy kiss that tasted of tea and smelled of lemon leaves. “Are you just going to sit there looking decorative all afternoon, or are you going to help me decide what to do with the obscene number of chillies the jalapeño plant has decided to produce?” Max smiled, closing his book and setting it aside. “I thought my role was to be decorative. It’s the one thing I was properly trained for.” The joke was light, devoid of the old bitterness. It was simply a fact from a past life, a country he no longer held a passport for. He stood up and followed Leo to the other side of the room where a pepper plant was laden with glossy, dark green fruit, a testament to Leo’s skill and the greenhouse’s perfect conditions.

As he began to carefully snip the peppers from their stems, dropping them into a ceramic bowl, Max found his thoughts drifting back. He remembered the man who used to stand behind a vast pane of glass, watching this same garden as if it were a television screen, a man who felt nothing but the phantom echo of a crowd. That man felt like a stranger now, a character in a biography he might have skimmed once. The roaring beast of the stadium hadn't been slain; it had simply been rendered irrelevant, its power fading in the face of a greater, quieter force. It couldn’t compete with the rustle of leaves in their greenhouse, with the sound of Leo’s quiet laughter, with the solid, reassuring weight of his head on Max’s shoulder as they fell asleep at night. His life, once a series of explosive, disconnected moments, had found a rhythm, a steady, seasonal cadence of planting and tending and harvesting, both in the garden and in his own heart.

Leo, watching him, saw the familiar, distant look of contemplation settle on his face. He reached out and gently took a chilli from Max’s hand, his fingers warm against Max’s skin. “Where’d you go?” he asked softly. Max looked up, his gaze focusing on the man before him, his anchor in this new, better world. “Nowhere,” he said, his voice thick with a gratitude that still, after all this time, felt fresh and overwhelming. “I was just thinking about planting that oak tree we talked about.” It was a plan they had made, a whim discussed over dinner one night. They wanted to plant a sapling at the far end of the garden, a native oak that would, in fifty years, become a giant, a new ancient tree for a future generation to admire. It was the most audacious, optimistic, and beautiful plan Max had ever been a part of. It was a statement of faith not just in each other, but in a future that stretched far beyond the length of a football career.

A slow smile spread across Leo’s face, understanding the unspoken meaning perfectly. “It’ll outlive both of us,” he said, his voice soft. “It’ll be here long after this house is gone. It needs good drainage and a lot of sun in its first few years.” He was already in problem-solving mode, but his eyes were shining with a love so deep and steady it felt as solid as the ground beneath their feet. He set the chilli down and stepped into Max’s space, wrapping his arms around his neck, the scent of soil and citrus and Leo himself enveloping Max in a familiar cloud of home. "We should do it this weekend," Leo murmured against his cheek. Max held him close, his own arms circling Leo’s waist, feeling the lean, strong line of his back. Outside, the rain softened to a fine mist. Inside, surrounded by the quiet, persistent life they had cultivated, the world was perfectly in order. He had everything he had ever truly needed, right here in his arms. The roar of the crowd was a ghost. This, this quiet, breathing life, was the only real victory.
